TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment certainly does not meet with my support. I will be vigorously opposing it, because it adds to the trivialisation of marriage in our society which has taken place since the institution of the Family Law Act in 1975. Since that time-that is, in the 10 years between 1976 and 1986-there have been 477,381 divorces and the number of children affected by marriages ending in divorce was 573,517. In addition, there is an enormous cost to our society in monetary terms. The cost of marriage breakdown in Australia to Federal taxpayers alone is over $2 billion. But, more particularly my attention, and the attention of other senators, should be directed to the trauma and personal cost involved in marriage breakdowns and the fact that the administration, the judges-whoever is to administer this law-are administering an unjust law, because the law does not take into account, so far as the definition of irretrievable breakdown of marriage is concerned, the conduct of either party. It is the only law I know of that does not take into account the conduct of the parties concerned, with the exception, I should say, of certain laws relating to compensation for accidents.

SPEECH.PARA: Marriage is no accident. The dissolution should not be regarded as some sort of accident over which nobody has any control. Yet, this Parliament is treating it as such. This Bill is a further example of the philosophical attitude that is the basis, and indeed the root cause, of many of the problems which confront our society. That problem is that persons do not meet the test of maturity. The test of maturity is where persons take responsibility for the consequences of their own actions. We in this Parliament are condoning the irresponsibility of some people who do not take and are not prepared to take responsibility for the consequences of their own actions.

So far as the dissolution of marriage is concerned-and I use the terms which are contained in the legislation-certain actions or certain principles are to be observed by the courts. I would like the Minister to respond and tell me and the chamber how these principles will be applied by the prescribed courts to which the jurisdiction of the Family Court will be transferred. I note amendment No. 6, as Senator Durack said, amends the previous clause 16. Whereas the previous clause 16 provided that proceedings for divorce may not be instituted in a court of summary jurisdiction, it is now proposed, as I read the amendment-and I may be wrong here-that applications for dissolution of marriage may be instituted in a court of summary jurisdiction, which is a prescribed court. I am not too sure in my own mind what is meant by `a prescribed court' because those courts will be prescribed by regulation. I know the Minister has dealt with this, but I am a little unclear about it. The underlying principle is established in section 43 of the Family Law Act, which states:

43. The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

(b) the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children;
(c) the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare; and
(d) the means available for assisting parties to a marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to the children of the marriage.

Frankly, if some of the Family Court jurisdiction is going to courts of summary jurisdiction, then what are the guidelines to be provided to those courts in order for them to apply the principles that are established in section 43 as I have just relayed them to the Senate? Section 14 of the Family Law Act states:

Where proceedings for a dissolution of marriage have been instituted, or financial or custodial proceedings have been instituted by a party to a subsisting marriage, it is the duty of the Judge or magistrate constituting the court and of every legal practitioner representing a party to give consideration, from time to time, to the possibility of a reconciliation of the parties.

If the Government is insistent upon this amendment and is insistent that in certain cases undefended matters-I will deal with this later-are to go to courts of summary jurisdiction, what arrangements are to be made for those courts to be apprised of the availability of reconciliation services in the areas where the application is lodged and where, as I think the legislation says, the parties to the marriage reside? If there are to be certain savings, where is the money to be made available to the reconciliation counselling services which now find it very difficult, because of their lack of funds, to meet the demands that are made of them?

I go to the question of undefended matters. Courts of summary jurisdiction will not be dealing only with undefended matters. The undefended matter here is divorce. of a value exceeding the amount in relation to which the court has jurisdiction in an action for the recovery of a debt;

In many cases it has to decide the title to the property as well, but further than that it is exercising this tremendous power actually to change the rights of ownership of property. Until now magistrates can only exercise that jurisdiction in respect of small items of property up to a value of $1,000.

Since the Family Law Act was passed in 1975 there has been considerable inflation. So probably $1,000 is not really an appropriate figure today. I am advised that the appropriate figure would be something more like $3,500. As I have said, the Government was proposing to increase the amount whatever the court's jurisdiction was in relation to the recovery of a debt. In New South Wales the jurisdiction is presently $5,000, but that is apparently to be increased to $10,000, or, where there is no car involved, $20,000. In Victoria the jurisdiction is presently $20,000, although there is a Bill to raise it to $40,000. In Queensland it is limited to $5,000 at the moment with a proposal to increase it to $20,000. In South Australia the jurisdiction is $7,500, with proposals, which may be in force now, to increase it to $20,000. In Tasmania the jurisdiction is only $5,000. In Western Australia it is $10,000. In the Northern Territory it is $10,000 and in the Australian Capital Territory it is $10,000, with drafting instructions to increase it to $50,000. In my experience, with the time it takes to get anything drafted in the Australian Capital Territory it will be a long time before it gets to $50,000, but that is by the way. At the moment it is $10,000 in the Australian Capital Territory.

That was a totally unsuitable proposal because not only is it a wrong concept to equate this question with the jurisdiction in debt recovery, but jurisdiction varies enormously around Australia, as this table to which I have just referred reveals. So at the last minute, up to just before 10 o'clock last Thursday morning, the Government realised that its proposition was quite at fault and that a uniform jurisdiction should be conferred in these very important matters of property disputes under the Family Law Act. Jurisdiction should be uniform around Australia and should be determined, not with reference to the jurisdiction of magistrates to deal with debt recovery but with reference to a sensible, uniform and appropriate figure. The Government has now come into this chamber and suggested that in lieu of that proposal-as I said it was its proposal until 10 o'clock last Thursday morning-and in lieu of the present figure of $1,000, there should be a figure of $20,000.

Does the article provide a valid justification for the reform of taxes on personal income in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. Indeed, I looked at it with some care, which will become apparent later. I was asked whether it presented an accurate picture of tax relativities between Australia and other countries. The answer to that is that it most certainly does not. The heading of the article, for example, was `Australia's Tax Rape'. The substance of it was compatible with that sort of shrieking, tabloid newspaper headline. It contained a number of factual errors and misconceptions. It was the sort of article and the sort of headline one would expect to see on the front page of the tabloids and not in any publication that has some pretensions to being an intellectual publication.

ANSWER.PARA: The article was purported to be based on a publication by Duesburys, entitled `Personal Taxes around the World', but, as I said before, very seriously misrepresented the factual information and/or misinterpreted it. Let me cite a couple of examples. At no stage did Duesburys claim that in Australia capital gains `are taxed at a flat rate of 49 per cent', as Mr Haselhurst asserted it did. At no stage did Duesburys attempt to misrepresent Australia's capital gains tax as an inheritance tax. On the contrary, Duesburys' booklet allows the reader to see that the capital gains taxes in countries such as the United States of America can be much heavier than in Australia, depending on how long the asset is held, the rate of inflation and the rate at which the nominal value of the asset increases.

What could have been a misconception or misinterpretation instead of a misrepresentation, which the earlier one was, was the claim by Mr Haselhurst that State income taxes, which apply in all but about six or seven United States States, are deductible against Federal taxation and that they therefore represent no additional tax. The conceptual error here is that, whilst it is true that a State income tax at a rate of, say, 10 per cent is deductible from the Federal income tax base in the United States, it is not deducted from the Federal income tax liability. Indeed, if the State tax was, say, 10 per cent, deductible against a Federal tax rate of 29 per cent-and these figures are illustrative only-the overall tax rate is 32 per cent, and not 25 per cent, as Mr Haselhurst suggested.

Finally, Mr Haselhurst juxtaposes in the article the 1987 social security tax rate for employees alongside the 1988 income tax rate scale. In other words, he fails to compare like with like and does not mention that in 1988 America's self-employed will pay social security tax of just over 13 per cent on their incomes in addition to State and Federal income tax. I have attempted to have these conceptual and factual errors corrected in that publication by writing a letter to the editor. Unfortunately, I failed to do so. I received a response from the editor which said that he has referred my letter to Mr Haselhurst and he will discuss the points and make use of a table attached to my letter showing that Australia ranks fourteenth or fifteenth, I think it is, on total income tax and not very far away on direct income taxes on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development scale when Mr Haselhurst returns to the subject in a forthcoming issue. I regard that as a very much less than satisfactory response. Any publication which has some intellectual pretensions-which I understand the Bulletin has-and which publishes an article so riddled with factual and conceptual errors and misrepresentation, as that article was, at least has an obligation to publish a letter which corrects some of the factual errors, misrepresentations and misinterpretations.

In Estimates committee hearings on 22 October 1987 the Minister stated that eight consultancy reports were being commissioned by the Government to examine the impact of World Heritage listing in north Queensland. I note that, in a Press statement reported in the Courier-Mail on 23 January, a spokesman for the Minister indicated that no reports were available and that the reports would not be finalised by February. Can the Minister advise whether he has now received any of these reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most of those consultants' reports have been received. They are under consideration by the Government. When we have considered them, as I have already indicated, I think in response to a question from Senator Durack last year, although I cannot recall the date, all those reports will be made public. Nothing will be swept under the carpet. It will all be there before the honourable senator's eyes. The difficulty will be whether or not he can see it or read it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Government paying $300,000 of taxpayers' money for those consultancy reports, when will the Minister table them so that the Senate can make a judgment on the World Heritage listing and its pros and cons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As soon as the Government has considered them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government given consideration to the role of State governments in implementing the program of micro-economic reform which has been foreshadowed by the Prime Minister? Do areas of administration which are currently the responsibility of the States possess an equivalent potential to achieve increases in efficiency, productivity and, therefore, national competitiveness to those areas of administration which are the responsibility of the Commonwealth? In what ways can State governments such as Queensland contribute to the process of micro-economic reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the first part of the question, the Government has given some consideration-I think it would be described as superficial or, rather, limited consideration at this stage-to what State governments may do in the area of micro-economic reform. My expectation is that there would be considerable potential for enhanced efficiency and productivity in that area. According to a document that I have received-an attachment to a Queensland Government Cabinet submission-there is enormous scope for such reform, productivity enhancement and efficiency improvement in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The document to which I refer could be described as a catalogue of bureaucratic inefficiency and duplication. It admits that in Queensland there is widespread duplication of functions as well as unnecessary functions. It exposes serious duplication in the data area, in land information systems and payroll systems and in professional and technical services such as laboratory functions and surveying. Support services such as motor vehicle fleets, printing, computing, photographic services and data collection are also heavily duplicated. It also makes the point that there is a variety of checking and inspection functions which are unnecessary.

The document does not specifically refer to the Bread Marketing Act of Queensland, which was passed to ensure that some National Party bakers were protected from competition from other bakeries-the sort of policy which is entirely consistent with free enterprise as it was practised in Queensland, is practised in Queensland and is endorsed by Senator Stone. Let it be noted for the record that that perverted version of free enterprise, which has flourished in Queensland for the past 30 years, is endorsed by Senator Stone. The document also refers to the gross inefficiency of a number of hospital and local fire brigade boards. I do not expect that too much will be done about that because they are probably all stacked full of National Party apparatchiks.

There is, however, most interestingly, a proposal to privatise electricity supply. There would be a huge potential, I would expect, not necessarily in privatising but in delivering electricity in Queensland more efficiently than it has been and is being delivered. The reason for that is that there are literally thousands of kilometres of Queensland Electricity Commission mains throughout western and north-western Queensland delivering power to sprawling National Party farms at enormous losses-losses which are carried at present by overcharging consumers on the coast and in the south-east. That is quite different from a telecommunications service, where it is essential, because of the nature of the service, to be plugged into a national grid.

Electricity can be generated almost anywhere, and the correct choice, of course, should be the lowest cost choice. But several decades of pork-barrelling by the National Party machine in Queensland in doing precisely that sort of thing-this is the political machine that Senator Stone identifies himself with and endorses-has lumbered the Queensland Electricity Commission with enormous capital costs. It supplies probably the highest priced or most costly electricity anywhere in Australia. Whilst it is a great pity-indeed, a tragedy-that that was done, it cannot really be unravelled immediately. Therefore, privatisation would not solve that problem. Indeed, it cannot be solved at this stage. But, if the system were to be privatised, I expect that it would be necessary to have a very substantial supplement in the Queensland Budget in order to carry the losses in that most cost-inefficient electricity delivery system in Australia, which are presently being carried by the extortion of customers in the south-east and on the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. How much money was spent on finding a departmental logo for the Department of Administrative Services? Is it a fact that all entries in the competition among officers of the Department were rejected?
—The answer to the first part of the question is $7,560. The answer to the second part of the question is yes.

—My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. What is the Government doing to ensure that the regional impact of the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) restructuring plan will not lead to negative impacts on women and men in regional centres which rely on these industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is well aware of the significance of the textile, clothing and footwear industries in a number of regional centres in Victoria and in other States. The Government is equally committed to improving the international competitiveness of our TCF industries, including promoting positive restructuring in the economy, and to ensuring that, in pursuing these objectives, particular sections of our community, particularly women and men in regional centres, are not required to bear any disproportionate burden as a result of this restructuring.

ANSWER.PARA: To achieve these dual objectives, the Government has made provision for the impact of TCF restructuring on regional centres to be monitored. Senator Button announced this in his statement to Parliament in June last year. He also stated at that time that, if adverse effects became apparent in regional centres, the Government would develop positive adjustment strategies for the affected centres. Senator Button will be introducing later this week a Bill to establish the TCF Development Authority and will, I am sure, speak about these aspects of the work of the proposed Authority. I am pleased to be able to advise that initial indications from some of the larger companies with operations in country and provincial cities are that new investment rather than concentration is anticipated as a result of the Government's plan for the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to a booklet entitled Privatisation-The Consumer Perspective, published at taxpayers' expense by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council. Is the Minister aware that the paper begins by claiming to be an attempt to examine objectively the issues involved, and that it then proceeds to quote a litany of anti-privatisation crusaders, such as Professor Ted Wheelwright, Hugh Stretton, New South Wales Minister for Housing Frank Walker and even John Langmore, who is cited as the sole authority for the proposition that United States of America and United Kingdom studies have shown that there is nothing intrinsically superior about performance under private ownership? Does the Minister agree that this tendentious and intellectually dishonest political pamphlet does nothing to advance the cause of rational debate about competition and efficiency in the public sector, let alone provide advice on matters of national consumer interest? Will the Minister investigate and report to the Senate on the circumstances in which the Council chose to focus on the issue of privatisation and by whom the draft document was prepared? Will the Minister invite the Chairman of the Council, Mr Justice Paul Stein, to resign as Chairman in order that the traditionally high standards of integrity attached to judicial office are not further compromised by another unedifying descent into the political arena?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering what Senator Alston was doing over the break. He has obviously been overseas gathering a certain degree of non-objectivity. It is interesting that when those on the other side approach an issue they disagree with, it immediately becomes tendentious and intellectual dishonesty. That is the claim Senator Alston is making about this publication. I tend to disagree with Senator Alston, and I ask him, in the spirit of democracy and in the spirit of the open debate that the Government is part of in terms of the privatisation issue, to look at this booklet with non-blinkered eyes and in the spirit of embracing all sorts of arguments from all parts of the political spectrum, as this booklet does. I have not had a close look at the booklet.
—Oh, come on! You spoke at Flinders University on privatisation. You know all about it.

—Senator Vanstone has learned all her rhetoric in the back streets of Adelaide and she is trying to bring it into the Senate. She should calm down for a moment. I was saying that I have not had a close look at the booklet but I have had a sufficiently close enough look at it to know that it encompasses more than what Senator Alston is projecting to the Senate. I think Senator Alston's request that I ask Justice Stein to resign is totally out of order. It is one that I will not entertain, and I am sure Senator Alston does not expect me to entertain it.

ANSWER.PARA: In closing I say that this booklet produced by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council is one part of the debate that is going on in the Australian community at the moment. The Government has already indicated that it welcomes comment from the whole spectrum of society. In this context I have noticed that Senator Alston has made some contribution to the debate over recent months. I put it to him that contrary to the allegation that he makes about the booklet being tendentious and intellectually dishonest, he should look at some of the statements he has made and assess them on that criterion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's supposedly close look at the document disclose that there were about 34 footnotes, and that the vast bulk of those were vehemently anti-privatisation? Does the Minister acknowledge that there is a plethora of literature these days that does advance the cause of privatisation, even on an objective basis, and that absolutely none of that was referred to, let alone properly considered, in that political pamphlet.

—I should stress the point that there are obviously implications for consumer interests and this portfolio when one looks at privatisation and at the principle of user pays. Members of the Opposition, who may not be closer to Senator Alston, have been making this point in recent debate. Let me also say to Senator Alston that I have more to do with my time than to read footnotes of booklets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I draw the Minister's attention to the statement in the Government's higher education Green Paper that the desired expansion of higher education graduates from the base of 88,000 a year to 125,000 by the year 2001 is unlikely to be achieved by `a major expansion in Commonwealth funding'. In view of this statement, has the Minister noted the views of Professor Ken McKinnon and Professor Karmel that the extra funds could be found by the Commonwealth? I quote Professor McKinnon:

QUESTION.PARA: On a current funding base of $2.4 billion, the extra money required to fund the extra places over the 13 years to the turn of the century could be found with a growth rate of approximately 2 per cent per annum, comfortably below reasonable expectations of the annual growth of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin referred to the desired-I think that was the word he used-increase from 88,000 to 125,000. I do not think that is quite compatible with the tone of the document. It was an indicative figure rather than a desired figure. Regarding what Professors McKinnon and Karmel said, I was not previously aware of that. They said the money could be found. I suppose that is true. The money could be found if there were complete funding from the Commonwealth Budget. It could be found if we raised taxes higher than they would otherwise have been or if some other area of government expenditure was cut below the level that would otherwise have applied. There is another way of course. We could bring in the sort of Budget that John Howard brought in in 1982. We could run an irresponsible fiscal policy and even that will work for a little while, but it will not go on working forever. Whether the advice of those two professors should be followed is, in the end, I suspect, more of a value judgment than an economic one. I am also aware of a statement made by an academic colleague of at least one of the other people mentioned, that is, Professor Helen Hughes, who said that she recognised that she was a member of the most protected industry in Australia.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On two occasions recently senators, in referring to standing order 364, have asked that documents quoted by senators who are not Ministers be tabled. Standing order 364 clearly contemplates that a motion be moved for the tabling of a paper quoted by a senator. Standing order 364 reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: A document quoted from by a Senator not a Minister for the Crown may be ordered by the Senate to be laid upon the Table; such Order may be made without Notice immediately upon the conclusion of the speech of the Senator who has quoted therefrom.

Senators have fallen into the practice of not moving a motion, but asking for the tabling of such documents. The difficulty with this is that senators who are not Ministers need leave to table a document. While leave may be granted at any time for a senator who is not a Minister to table a document, this has nothing to do with standing order 364. It is suggested that, if senators want to make use of standing order 364, they move a motion in accordance with the standing order. The alternative is for the senator who quotes from a document to seek leave to table it. I will circulate this statement to all senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Lewis moving a motion of which he gave notice earlier this day.

I move that motion not only because of what has occurred in the other place today-that is, the refusal of the Government to take up the motion of the Opposition that it should explain its position with respect to Dr Blewett's inexcusable breach of the privacy of Australian citizens over the last few days-but also because of the contemptuous way in which issues touching on the privacy of Australians have been dealt with by senators in Question Time today.

I remind the Senate that in Question Time today Senator Puplick addressed a question to Senator Cook. He referred to the improper release of data by Dr Blewett to a Government backbencher. He also referred to previous releases of personal information relating to medical practitioners, for example, during the New South Wales doctors dispute of April-May 1985, and to other details of breaches of the confidentiality which supposedly applies with respect to these medical records. I remind the Senate of the quite extraordinary way that Senator Cook chose to respond to that question. He expressed some considerable concern at the fact that medical practitioners had dared to charge more than what he called the recommended fee when in fact there is no recommended fee. There is a schedule fee which relates to the amount of refund made by Medicare to doctors or to their patients.

The most worrying thing about the answer by Senator Cook was that in some peculiar way he seemed to think that the quite legal activities of doctors in charging other than the schedule fee was something which justified the illegal release of private information which could touch upon not only the rights of doctors but also the rights of any Australian who is obtaining medical treatment in this country from a medical practitioner. There is no other explanation for the--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Senator Chaney used the words `illegal release of documents'. That has not been established. It is contrary to the evidence in statements by the Government. I ask for the removal of that phrase.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. There clearly is no point of order because there are a number of cases in which information has been released contrary to the terms of the statute. The really worrying thing is that a Minister in this place can suggest that, because people have behaved in a way which was contrary to the way that this Government believed they should behave, that justified the release of confidential information about them. That is a reminder of the debates that have taken place in this chamber with respect to the identity card and other issues.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the other point I wish to raise in moving this motion. The first question asked in Question Time today was to Senator Walsh about proposals by the Government to introduce a tax file numbering system. The Opposition sought information about whether this system would be introduced, whether the details of it would be provided to the Australian people or whether that was being withheld pending the New South Wales State election. It is quite interesting that in his reply Senator Walsh referred to the debates which had taken place with respect to the identity card. I remind the Senate of the words he used about the arguments against the identity card. Senator Walsh talked about the `spurious veil' which was being drawn--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: Senator Chaney is moving a motion for the suspension of standing orders. It seems to me that what he is talking about goes to the substance of that debate and not to an argument for the suspension of Standing Orders. I know, Mr President, that you had difficulty in ruling on this matter in a previous debate of particular relevance to me. But I submit that the honourable senator is now widely outside the standing orders that allow a debate on the suspension of Standing Orders and the evidence for its justification. Senator Chaney is clearly debating the substance of the arguments that will follow once the suspension is allowed, if that so happens. I ask you, Mr President, to rule that he is not debating the suspension of Standing Orders but that he is going to the substance of the arguments he wants to put later.

—On the point of order, Mr President: The clear obligation on me in moving this motion is to explain to the Senate why the Opposition believes that Standing Orders should be suspended and this matter should be dealt with now. My remarks so far have related to the evidence of the last hour that this is a matter about which the Senate is entitled to be concerned. As it happens, it is proposed that I should speak only on the suspension motion. It is our wish to move the substantive motion, which will be moved by Senator Lewis. I understand that the Government will not be opposing the motion. I do not wish to detain the Senate at any great length but, as far as the point of order is concerned, quite clearly it is incumbent on me to show why we regard this as a matter that should be brought forward now. I ask for your ruling, Mr President.

—I intervene somewhere between Senator Chaney and Senator Crowley on this matter. The Government will not oppose the suspension of Standing Orders. I have indicated that to Senator Chaney. Normally when the suspension of Standing Orders is sought, as I understand it, the practice in the Senate is to give a brief explanation as to why that suspension is sought. I hope that, because of the circumstances which I have outlined, that will be the case. Senator Chaney seemed to be getting into full flight when Senator Crowley intervened. Once that happens, he can go on for a long time. I hope that Senator Chaney will accept the view that I have just put, even if you, Mr President, do not rule on it.

—There is no point of order. Unfortunately, we have not adopted the sessional order that would have limited this debate. Senator Chaney can speak only to the suspension of Standing Orders, and I ask him to do so.

—The interventions by Senator Crowley are a very good reason for not adopting a new standing order. She has taken up most of the time so far by raising spurious points of order. No doubt that could be done if there was a five-minute time limit on speakers. That certainly convinces me, Mr President, that the proposed reform is one that should not be adopted by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I return briefly to the case which I wish to make, for the reasons which I have outlined-namely, that we believe that the Senate should carry this motion and we should deal with the substantive motion. The simple fact is that in the House of Representatives today the Government has shown contempt for these proper matters of concern about the privacy of Australian citizens. Today two Senate Ministers, in answers to questions, have shown the same contempt. I believe that the hundreds of thousands of Australians who campaigned against the identity card will note Senator Walsh's reference to spurious veils being drawn against the attempt to cover up illicit activities. That is an argument they would reject with contempt and which I reject with contempt. I simply say there are serious matters here which go to the privacy of Australians, and which go to important issues of civil liberties. They should not be treated with the contempt that has been shown them by the Government in this chamber today, and I therefore commend the motion to the Senate. I ask that we pass the motion and allow Senator Lewis to move his motion forthwith.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Hawke Labor Government for its failure to protect the privacy of Australian citizens.

I move straight to the admissions made by the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett-he is not a doctor of medicine; he is a doctor of philosophy-made in the House of Representatives yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?

—Someone over there interjects `So what?' in regard to Dr Blewett. I say that because a lot of the members of the community originally thought that he was a doctor of medicine and held him in some high regard for that. Since then their regard for him has fallen considerably. He is no longer held in high regard by either the medical profession or the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday Dr Blewett conceded in the House of Representatives that he had misled the Parliament but, further than that, that he had in fact provided the honourable member for Canning, Mr Gear, with material containing information which enabled the doctors about whom the statistics had been released to be identified.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?
—Senator Schacht says `How?'. Let me explain. Yesterday afternoon Dr Blewett, in stating that Mr Gear was provided with information, said:

SPEECH.PARA: He was provided, through my office, with material containing no identification of doctor, provider number, or patient . . .
That is what he said in his original answer. He subsequently came back into the chamber and said:
The HIC-
the Health Insurance Commission-
has informed me this afternoon that its advice to me was in error and that contrary to earlier advice, some provider numbers were included with the statistical information.
So the provider numbers, which identify the doctors, were provided to Mr Gear. That is contrary to the Health Insurance Act.

Let me go straight to one of Dr Blewett's great defences. What he is in effect saying is that it was the HIC which provided him with the material and it was in error-as though it was the HIC's fault. But he conceded, to quote from what he said to the House of Representatives yesterday:
It is my office practice to ensure that the relevant information is complied with in respect of any statistical material from the HIC which may have passed through the office. It-
that is, his office-
does this by checking that the material does not contain anything that would identify either doctors or patients.

So Dr Blewett claims that the HIC gave him material which contained this information, and the poor old HIC was terribly wrong in doing this. But he also claims that his office checks all that material anyway. So, right from the word go, he has confessed his own guilt.

However, Dr Blewett is guilty not simply of misleading the Parliament. Of course he could be forgiven for that because he came straight back into the Parliament after his office had checked out the answer and said, `I was wrong: I gave you the wrong answer'. Anyone can accept that a Minister during Question Time could give the wrong answer, but this Minister confessed in the course of his explanation that he had committed a breach of his own Act, the Health Insurance Act.

The Act is relevant in discussing whether or not this action is an offence. It would be difficult enough for a Minister to come before the Parliament and admit that he had been charged with some offence not relating to his office; for example, a drink-driving offence. In that event undoubtedly the Parliament would challenge him and there would be all sorts of debate about his propriety and whether he should remain a Minister as a result of the offence with which he was charged. This is not that sort of a case. This is an offence arising directly out of the Minister's own actions in the administration of his Department and the administration of his portfolio, and out of his own personal responsibility as Minister for Community Services and Health. His actions are covered by his own Act, and he has acted illegally according to that Act. That is an offence that is totally different from the sort of offence that I referred to before which some Minister might commit outside his portfolio. This is an offence specifically within the administration of his own portfolio.

I understand that the Solicitor-General has advised that on the basis of certain presumptions, to which I will draw honourable senators' attention, the Minister has not committed a criminal offence. What the Solicitor-General has said, in effect, is that a prima facie case has been established against the Minister but that if the Minister would like to go into the witness box and give sworn evidence that he did not know the material supplied to Mr Gear contained this information, and it was not within his reasonable ability to ascertain that that was contrary to the Act, it may be that he would be acquitted of the criminal charge laid against him. The point is that the Minister should not be a Minister of the Crown until that matter has been resolved by the courts in his favour, or dealt with otherwise. It may very well be that he is able to establish before a court of law that he was not guilty of the offence--

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have to be a technical defence.

—As my colleague Senator Chaney says, technically he may not be guilty of a criminal offence, but there can be no doubt that what he has done here is release confidential information about the medical profession of Australia to his colleague Mr Gear for crass political purposes to do with trying to denigrate the medical profession of Australia. It is as clear as anything that that it what it was for. He wanted to put down the medical profession of Australia by saying that doctors are overcharging in some way. To do that he released this material, contrary to statute. I believe that Dr Blewett would not be able to establish to the satisfaction of a court that he is not guilty of an offence, because I doubt the so-called defences raised by the Solicitor-General in his advice.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the minute paper tabled in the Senate today by Senator Cook. I draw attention to the fact that this minute, written by Mr Wilcox, the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission, is dated 7 January 1988-months after the horse had bolted from the stable, because the material was released to Mr Gear back in the middle of 1987. In January of 1988, when Mr Wilcox realises the nature of the offence which he and the Commission have committed, contrary to the Act-because there is no doubt that they as well as the Minister have acted contrary to the Act-Mr Wilcox writes to the Minister and says:

Last year the Commission supplied your office with information about the charging behaviour of a sample of different specialist groups . . . The information supplied to your office did not identify either the doctors or their patients.

That is what Mr Wilcox wrote to the Minister on 7 January in an attempt to enable the Minister to escape. That letter contains an untruth. It says that it did not identify the doctors, whereas we now know that it did identify the doctors because it contained the provider number-that is, the service number by which each doctor in Australia is identified. This letter then suggested a response to the Minister to be written to Dr Passmore. That response contains within it a paragraph which absolutely destroys Dr Blewett. Mr Wilcox is suggesting that Dr Blewett write the following paragraph to Dr Passmore:
You have my assurance that no data identifying either doctors or their patients was provided by my Office or the Commission to Mr Gear.

As soon as Dr Blewett saw that paragraph, he knew that he could not give such an assurance because by then he had come to realise that the data identifying the doctors had, in fact, been provided by the office of the Commission and had been available to Mr Gear. In fact, Mr Wilcox has condemned his own Minister by this correspondence. If Dr Blewett is able to have himself acquitted on some sort of criminal charge, that is a matter for Dr Blewett's own personal satisfaction. But the point which I raise in this debate is not Dr Blewett in particular, but the failure of this Government to protect the privacy of Australian citizens. How could the people of Australia trust this Government in any way? It was proposed that the Minister, Dr Blewett, would be in charge of the Australia Card administration.

I refer to six instances of the release of information by Dr Blewett contrary to the privacy provisions which apply in relation to health statistics. Firstly, let me talk about May 1985 during the New South Wales doctors dispute when he released HIC information to the Sun-Herald newspaper. Honourable senators will remember the row that erupted as a result of the release of that information. In April 1986 the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances had to disallow the health insurance regulations because they would have allowed this Minister to release information from the HIC to people not connected with the health industry.

I turn now to the case of Dr McGoldrick, a Collins Street specialist who faced a committal hearing on 11 charges of using an instrument or other means to procure abortions. He was cleared of the charges. But this was another case of the invasion of a person's privacy. The charges were based on the release of confidential records disclosing the sex lives of 11 teenage girls. The records were released by the Commission and led to a raid by the police upon Dr McGoldrick's surgery. The magistrate in the case said that the records had been unlawfully obtained but, worse, as a result of the release of that information a woman who was to be a witness lost her job. She had been the victim of computer matching and cross-referencing aimed at discovering which women had abortions administered by Dr McGoldrick. I say to the Australian Labor Party (ALP) that the women of Australia were very angry at what happened under the administration of Dr Blewett in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a shameful exercise. The Minister should not be laughing.

—Yes, I agree with my colleague, Senator Knowles. The medical profession was also very angry with what happened. This is the man who, in November 1986, wrote a letter to Dr McNicol in the Australian Capital Territory in which he said that only 20 officers within the Department of Community Services and Health had access to confidential information on doctors' incomes. In fact, in due course there was a memorandum from Mr John Loy, Mr Young's former senior private secretary, to Dr Blewett's private secretary which disclosed that the Australian Federal Police investigations had identified 197 people throughout Australia who had access to the Health Insurance Commission's information on doctors' incomes. How on earth could we in any way trust this Minister with any confidential information? It makes an absolute mockery of Dr Blewett's statement in that letter to Dr McNicol in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: My Department makes every effort to safeguard confidential information.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a joke!

—It is a joke. On 18 November 1986, Dr Blewett indicated in the House of Representatives that identification data could be released to various community leaders for verification. On 23 February 1988 we were faced with the revelation that he provided his colleague, Mr Gear, with all sorts of confidential information in relation to doctors' salaries and that it was being used for political purposes. That is what it was all about. It is not as if it was to do with some sort of statistical arrangements. It was to be used specifically for the purpose of an attack by Mr Gear on the medical profession. I ask: `What next from Dr Blewett?'. I say to Senator Button-I see him sitting at the table and I presume that as Leader of the Government in the Senate he will respond to this-`Do you appreciate what this is doing to the fabric of ministerial responsibility in this nation? How can we trust any statements made by any Ministers while they have got this bad apple among their number? How can we trust them when they stand up and give us some assurance that they will do something? For all we know they may retire or lose their position and we would have Dr Blewett as the responsible Minister to carry out the undertaking, or whatever it is, that they would be providing us with. How can we trust them while we have this bad apple in there rotting away at the core of the Westminster system?'. What other material will Dr Blewett reveal next? Will he be looking, for example, at the acquired immune deficiency syndrome positive people in Australia and disclosing information about their number and what doctors are treating them? Will he be looking at sexually transmitted diseases, or any of the other matters which people believe it is their right to keep as their own personal information or confidential between them and their doctor? It is certainly not confidential to Dr Blewett or his confidants and certainly not confidential to the members of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the proposed wealth inquiry that this Government was going to conduct. We have not heard much about it lately because we have got an election coming up in New South Wales. But when that election is over no doubt the Labor Party will, once again, resurrect its proposed wealth inquiry in which the people of Australia will be required to supply all sorts of information regarding their own personal wealth. Will that material be confidential or will it be available for distribution among people? We hear that the Government has now put the extended tax file number system on hold until after the New South Wales election. Again, that will provide the Government with all sorts of statistical information applicable to individuals around Australia. Again, we ask the question: Will that remain confidential? How could we trust any of these Australian Labor Party Ministers of the Crown? It is very reminiscent of the last time we had an Australian Labor Government under Mr Whitlam and the sort of behaviour that was going on there. This Government and this Minister have disclosed themselves as being totally untrustworthy. Indeed, as I said before, this Minister should resign-there is no question about that-until the question of his guilt or innocence of this offence has finally been resolved by the courts of the land. Having not resigned, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of this country should have dismissed him until that situation had occurred. Having lost three Ministers, this Government is in a situation where it will not allow a Minister to resign and will not dismiss a Minister; it has not got the courage.

I note that we have in the Senate a Minister who has confessed to misleading the Senate. Of course, he has not resigned either. So really there are five Ministers in this Government who have been or are in trouble, but they are trying desperately to ride out the troubles that they now have. I say to the Senate that this Minister should resign. The Prime Minister should have sacked this Minister for his behaviour. Indeed, this Government should be condemned for its total failure to treat the confidential affairs of the people of Australia with the privacy to which they are entitled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button has said quite rightly that we ought to be looking at the facts of the matter. There are plenty of facts involving the leaking or releasing of confidential information about individuals during the term of the Hawke Labor Government. We are not debating Dr Blewett's academic qualifications or whether individual doctors were identified by the recently released information. We are debating the fact that there was potential, and still is potential, for identification of those individual doctors and that Dr Blewett is the Minister responsible for the release that has led to that potential.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion before the Senate today is one which we will be supporting-Senator Button got that part right, at least-because it quite properly condemns the Hawke Labor Government for its failure to protect the privacy of Australian citizens. The Hawke Government's record in this area of privacy protection or, in its case, lack of privacy protection, is appalling. We need to ask ourselves why. Is it mere incompetence? Is it lack of interest in the area? Is it both? Or is it something a little more sinister than that? The basis for the Government's stance on privacy legislation is probably best summarised by a statement made by one of its own Ministers, ironically Dr Blewett, the Minister who is currently in the hot seat-a hot seat which appears to be filling rapidly with a stack of Ministers. Dr Blewett defined privacy as `a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property', which he presumably does not support any more than the right to privacy. That just about says it all. When one looks at this Government's record one sees that it does not support the right to privacy, it does not support the right to private anything, on the grounds that they are bourgeois rights.

The latest revelations of leaked confidential information from the Health Insurance Commission, which seems to be making a habit of this, show just how right many of us in this chamber and elsewhere were to fear the Australia card and to question the Government's commitment to privacy legislation. The ID card proposal was neither more nor less than a numbering system for all Australians, instituted to enable the bureaucracy to gather data on ordinary citizens and to keep them under surveillance.

Whatever else the Government might have said, the threat to civil liberties posed by the proposed national identification system for Australia, euphemistically and laughingly called the Australia Card, cannot be overstated. The nature of that threat was clearly recognised by the electorate ultimately and almost too late. The concerns that we expressed here, that were finally expressed out in the community, were shown to be justified by the Government's very cavalier attitude to leaked documents that had been brought to the Parliament's attention and to the attention of the public from time to time. Thousands of Australian citizens, many of whom had nothing else much in common, joined together to fight the Australia Card last year precisely because to them it represented a gross threat to privacy, an invasion of their civil liberties and something that they were not prepared to countenance.

Apart from our concern and their concern about the Australia Card proposal, we knew that the Government wanted and planned to put responsibility for that card, for that data system, for the citizens covered by that data system, into the hands of the Health Insurance Commission, a body which had given medical files on teenage girls to the Victoria Police and which had leaked details of doctors' incomes to the Sunday newspapers in order, presumably, to blackmail them during the New South Wales doctors dispute, which, allegedly, according to some Sydney doctors, meant that, amongst other things, some of those Sydney doctors had access to confidential information and parameters regarding allowable levels of over-servicing for medical and diagnostic services per patient. The allegations by those Sydney doctors were that they had access, courtesy of the Health Insurance Commission, to confidential information regarding doctors' Medicare income.

There were also allegations of the use of leaked confidential Health Insurance Commission information for the purposes of fraud and over-servicing generally and threats of personal injury and actual malicious damage to property. Those things had all been revealed to the Parliament and to the public during a time when the Government was arguing that the appropriate body to have oversight of the centralised data system known as the Australia Card was the Health Insurance Commission.

There have also been reports over recent years about the finding of Department of Social Security microfiche on pensions and benefits under a hedge in a Melbourne suburb, of children bringing computer sheets home from school containing Medicare information and of frequent complaints from patients about their medical records being disclosed without authorisation. I am not sure, but I thought I heard a comment from the Government benches saying that that has nothing to do with it. I would have thought that it had everything to do with it. Information is collected, collated and stored by government departments under the responsibility of Ministers. It is only right and proper that that information is retained by them on a purely confidential basis. Whilst not many people go poking around under Melbourne hedges, enough of them do to discover that sort of information. It can prove extremely embarrassing and very damaging to certain individuals. These, then, were the very bureaucracies that the Government wished further to empower in gathering data on Australian citizens.

The Government claimed that despite all of these things there was still no need for concern. Somehow a magic wand was going to be waved over the Health Insurance Commission that would ensure that never again, once it was given oversight of all the information, would any of it leak out, would any unauthorised, confidential, private information be put in the hands of anyone who should not have it. The Government claimed further that the privacy legislation associated with the ID card would protect privacy adequately. That claim, too, was a nonsense. For a start, the Government's model was the Swedish model, a model it was putting forward as ideal at the very time the head of the Swedish body was resigning because he said that the Swedish system simply was not working.

The Law Council of Australia pointed out that the Government's proposed Data Protection Agency was no real weapon for protecting the privacy of Australian citizens because it could act only after the event, when the damage had been done. Much good privacy protection is then! Academics around the country and legal experts in the Australian Privacy Foundation were unanimous in their view that the card represented an appalling threat to privacy and that the Government's so-called protection against this simply would not work. How could it? It had not in the past, through the Health Insurance Commission; it was unlikely to with the weak privacy protection legislation that the Government was including in its package and the very watered down Data Protection Agency.

To make matters worse, of course, when the Government was finally forced to abandon its ID card plans it cynically dumped its privacy legislation too. Had it proceeded with that last year, Dr Blewett certainly would not be in and the bureaucrats in the Health Insurance Commission may not be in the predicament in which they currently find themselves. Every word that has been said during the ID card debate about how important privacy legislation was, how long it has been needed, is still valid. Any statements by the Government that echoed this have proved to be empty rhetoric with its abandonment of that legislation. No more has been seen of the legislation and the Government has been silent on the subject ever since. The Australian Democrats, through my colleague, Senator Michael Macklin, did introduce a private member's Bill on privacy protection to fill the vacuum but we in this place know just what sort of precedence is given to private member's Bills and how much use that Bill is likely to be unless the Government changes its mind and moves to pick up this area. As Senator Macklin pointed out at the time, ID card or no ID card, privacy protection in Australia is long overdue as the Australian Law Reform Commission report and other studies have shown.

To bring us back to the central point of this debate, only in the last 24 hours have we had further evidence of the need for such protection and of Dr Blewett's cavalier attitude. Obviously he has had no occasion to change his earlier views about the bourgeois right to privacy and about there being no need therefore to afford it a great deal of protection. The Age reported today that Dr Blewett admitted his office had given a Labor backbencher confidential Medicare information on doctors who overcharged. Apart from the embarrassment to Dr Blewett and the fact that he had to correct an earlier answer he had given in the Parliament, one wonders when he and his colleagues will ever learn. Attempting to dismiss this as `an honest mistake', a phrase which is becoming very capable of being sent up--

TALK.START.PARA: —Debased.

—`Debased', Senator Messner says, but it has certainly become the objective of satire in this place in recent weeks. Attempting to dismiss this as an honest mistake simply will not do. Dr Blewett was the Minister responsible. He apparently knew of the discussions between his office and the Health Insurance Commission. So we are talking here about information which was released by a Department over which Dr Blewett had responsibility, information released by that Department which was supposed to be absolutely confidential. As I said earlier, the fact that the provider number may not be able to be used by the backbencher concerned or anybody else to identify individual doctors does not mean it is not possible to do so if somebody gets the key. I have no particular truck for doctors who overcharge or who try to defraud the system but the law as it is at the moment gives those practitioners, and everybody else, the right to have information on them kept confidential. It is our responsibility in this place, and surely the Minister's responsibility, to ensure that that law is abided by.
—Senator Haines, do you approve on moral grounds that doctors should in fact charge above the schedule fee?

—If Senator Cook had listened he would have heard me say that I have no time for doctors who overcharge, try to defraud the system or anything else. That is not the point: the point is that at the moment the law says they are entitled to have information which is collected and collated on them retained as confidential. I repeat: we in this place-and certainly the Minister responsible-ought to have as our primary function ensuring that the law as it stands is obeyed. If we want to change the law that is another matter entirely but that is not what we are talking about now. What we are talking about here is information which was supposed to be kept absolutely confidential. It related to medical information about private citizens who are also entitled to expect that confidentiality will be scrupulously protected.

SPEECH.PARA: When Senator Cook talks about moral points, does he think it is valid in a chase after doctors who are ripping off the system that we reveal publicly sensitive information about the medical conditions and the treatments provided for those medical conditions of ordinary Australian citizens? I certainly hope not. It is quite unacceptable for such information to be turning up in court cases, to be given to backbenchers for use on a committee and to be splashed all over the front pages of newspapers. All these things have happened in recent years-it was most recently revealed yesterday-under this Government because the state of privacy protection under this Government is inadequate and the only legislation extant in the area, as I said earlier, is a private member's Bill introduced by the Australian Democrats. Most of these incidents have emanated from the Health Insurance Commission and that should put us on our guard in future, particularly as the next specific proposal from this Government will almost certainly be for an upgraded tax file number. As Senator Lewis said, this will not be until after the New South Wales election. Nevertheless that is likely to be the next proposal.

I remind honourable senators that this proposal will be coming from a government that put up the dangerous and potentially destructive ID card accompanied by some hopelessly inadequate privacy protection legislation and whose Ministers' offices have been known to leak confidential information to the media. It does not take long to work out the probable direction of the upgraded tax file number. It will be, if this Government has any say in the matter, simply an ID card in disguise. I think it is worth repeating something that I said in October last year in a debate about the ID card and tax file numbers. An upgraded tax file number, a high integrity tax file number, can certainly be extremely useful in eliminating at least some more tax evasion in this country; it should not be used, however, as an ID card by another name. `Upgraded' and `high integrity' are not synonyms for `randomly extended'. I think we need to be careful that the Government does not come into this place and say, `Ah, but all the Opposition parties recommended that a tax file number should be upgraded, given higher integrity, and this is what we are doing'. The Government should not attempt to extend its use in all sorts of other areas and then cry that we on this side of the chamber have done an about-face. I warn the Government now that if it thinks it can try to sneak in an Australia Card by the back door it is very much mistaken.

I have no doubt that the Government will pursue its elaborate proposals for data collection, backed up by bureaucracies that are just itching to get their hands on as much data as possible, or worse, I suppose, itching to use it against private citizens, often for purely political purposes. I suggest that the time is long overdue for privacy protection laws in this country-privacy protection laws which have some teeth and some meaning, which are wide-ranging and properly enforceable. At the very least, they should encompass the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) guidelines covering such things as purpose specification principles and use limitation principles. As to the latter, I might add that, had we had such legislation, the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia would not have been able to misuse the information on people's payslips in the way that it did a few years ago to find out which members of the Public Service were or were not members of unions. The OECD guidelines also look at openness, accountability and security safeguards. Rather than read them all out, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the OECD principles with regard to privacy.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Exhibit 1: The OECD Principles
Collection Limitation Principle
1. There should be limits to the collection of personal data and any such data should be obtained by lawful and fair means and, where appropriate, with the knowledge or consent of the data subject.
Data Quality Principle
2. Personal data should be relevant to the purposes for which they are to be used, and, to the extent necessary for those purposes, should be accurate, compete and kept up-to-date.
Purpose Specification Principle

3. The purposes for which personal data are collected should be specified not later than at the time of collection and the subsequent use limited to the fulfilment of those purposes or such others as are not incompatible with those purposes and as are specified on each occasion of change of purpose.
Use Limitation Principle
4. Personal data should not be disclosed, made available or otherwise used for purposes other than those specified in accordance with [Principle 3] except:
(a) with the consent of the data subject; or
(b) by the authority of law.
Security Safeguards Principle
5. Personal data should be protected by reasonable security safeguards against such risks as loss or unauthorised access, destruction, use, modification or disclosure of data.
Openness Principle

6. There should be a general policy of openness about developments, practices and policies with respect to personal data. Means should be readily available of establishing the existence and nature of personal data, and the main purposes of their use, as well as the identity and usual residence of the data controller.
Individual Participation Principle
7. An individual should have the right:
(a) to obtain from the data controller, or otherwise, confirmation of whether or not the data controller has data relating to him;
(b) to have communicated to him, data relating to him
(i) within a reasonable time;
(ii) at a charge, if any, that is not excessive;
(iii) in a reasonable manner; and
(iv) in a form that is readily intelligible to him;
(c) to be given reasons if a request made under sub-paragraphs (a) and (b) is denied, and to be able to challenge such denial; and
(d) to challenge data relating to him and, if the challenge is successful, to have the data erased, rectified, completed or amended.
Accountability Principle
8. A data controller should be accountable for complying with measures which give effect to the principles stated above.

Community leaders! While they make allegations against Minister Blewett, a man of absolute integrity, a man widely respected in Australia as a man of ethics, morality and integrity, where do they stand with Sinclair on the Asia Dairy issue?
