Where do they stand with Durack on the inquiry of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? On all those matters, which were much more serious, much more substantial, they did not apply the standards they now seek to apply to an honourable man. They did not apply these standards to their own kind. The hypocrisy and the double standards are well and truly answered. What did Dr Blewett do? Dr Blewett has answered that question in the Parliament. He has put a statement down in the chamber of the House of Representatives which says exactly what he did.

TALK.START.PARA: —He misled the Parliament. He evaded the question.

—If the honourable senator keeps interjecting, I might just read it out. She obviously has not read it, is not familiar with the case and is interjecting out of ignorance. What Dr Blewett did was correct an error that had been made. That is the honest man's reaction to an error. That is the right and proper thing to do. There is nothing anywhere in the whole Westminster structure of government that says that, in circumstances such as that, anyone should resign.
—The error is the provider number.
—The day when Senator Parer commits no errors will be the day on which I give him the right to make that interjection. People do make errors. They are fallible. That is the nature of individuals.
—You are admitting an error by the Minister. You have just blown your case.

—I have not just blown my case. I am paraphrasing what Minister Blewett has got in his statement. I stand absolutely foursquare on that statement and nothing that I say departs from it. But when these things occur the test of moral correctness is whether they are corrected or not. What did Blewett do? He came straight back and corrected it and, more than that, instituted an inquiry to find out what had happened. That is the action of a responsible person. Since a number of legal positions have been brandished around in this debate, let me say that I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has tabled in the House of Representatives the view of the Solicitor-General with respect to the issues under question.
—Looking after another first best friend.

—Does the honourable senator not place any weight on the views of the Solicitor-General? Does she not believe in anything? If the Solicitor-General is not entitled to have a view about this, although he is the proper officer to be consulted, and if the honourable senator is not interested in it, all she is interested in is a witch hunt. I am interested in establishing the facts here. Let me now establish them. The Solicitor-General has offered the opinion that the Minister has breached the requirements of secrecy of the relevant provisions of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act, and that is inclusive of sections 1, 5 and 14. Wild allegations have been made in this debate that something unlawful or illegal was done by Minister Blewett, by his staff or by anyone else. The learned opinion of a distinguished lawyer-the Solicitor-General, no less-is that that is not the case. But do we hear any attempts to withdraw because of that? No, we do not. All we hear is an attempt to beat up this debate. I think that when the records of these censure motion debates-one occurred last night and there was another one today in the House of Representatives-are read, this matter will be shown to be nothing more than, frankly, a storm in a teacup. The statement that Minister Blewett put down answers all of the points.

SPEECH.PARA: On the issue of confidentiality, what is clear is that Dr Blewett acted properly. Once he had discovered what had occurred, the inquiry was instituted. The opinion of the Solicitor-General on what has now occurred is such as to exonerate the participants. The material that was released to individuals was, to all intents and purposes, something that could not be deciphered and something of which intelligent use could not be made unless one had the key to what those figures meant. George Gear, the honourable member for Canning, is the person who had that information. He came forward straightaway and said quite clearly, honestly and openly in the Parliament as well as in the community-there was no question of his hiding behind privilege-that he had not given out that information, that he did not understand what the figures meant.

As I am running out of time, if honourable senators want to hear the rest of George Gear's statement they should obtain a transcript of what was said this morning on the AM program. His whole demeanour in answering the questions put by the journalist was one of absolute surprise that in fact he had in his possession any information that was useful or intelligible or in fact information that was damaging to anyone at all. He went on to make the point that, as chairman of the price watch committee, a number of patients complained to him about doctors. Those patients gave him the names of the doctors they complained about. They produced to him file numbers. But on no occasion has he released the names of the doctors complained of by people who approached him as chairman of the price watch committee. He has observed commendable levels of public integrity.

If I may summarise the case, in the end the situation comes down to the fact that the Opposition would dearly love-it is down on its bended knees praying-to have something on this Government. It has not. The idea that it has not has not yet dawned on it. It is loath to let go of the idea because it is such a seductive and attractive one. But if the Opposition goes through the record step by step it will realise that there is nothing there. That is its cause for regret. The bellow we hear from the Opposition benches is one of frustration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief contribution to the debate. I shall vote against this motion but I wish to make clear why I propose to do so. I certainly agree with the sentiments of the motion as written. However, the motion has been used as a Dr Blewett bash, as we have all heard. I do not wish to support a bash. I do not have a brief for Dr Blewett either; I do not wish to defend or detract from Dr Blewett. It is just that I decry the predilection of people in this place and the other place for kicking heads rather than debating issues. Had some substantial contribution been made to a privacy debate, or had a privacy Bill been introduced or something like that, I would have been happy to vote for it. However, this has been nothing more than an attack on a person. I think it is a disgrace.
—It is a disgrace that you agree with what Blewett did.
—Senator Knowles is talking about things being a disgrace. I think it is a disgrace that people attack the person and not the office, and that people attack the person and not the issue.
—Someone has to be responsible for the office.
—I believe people have to be responsible, but the way to be responsible is to clearly debate the issues and to take clear and definitive action rather than indulge in the kicking of heads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to close the debate. I was interested to hear Senator Wood's words. I agree with some of his sentiments. However, I do not know where he has been during the debate. He seems to have got the bat by the wrong end or something. The truth of this matter is that those speaking in support of this motion have been repeatedly drawing attention to the fact that the current matter involving Dr Blewett is simply one of many examples-the latest example-of this Government's failure to protect privacy. My motion seeks to condemn the Hawke Labor Government for its failure to protect the privacy of Australian citizens. If Senator Wood had been listening to the debate he would have heard the Labor speakers-Senator Button and Senator Cook-do as they always do when the Labor Party is under attack, and that is to turn to personal abuse of those people in this chamber who have the audacity to put forward a proposition that one of their number has committed an offence against the parliamentary traditions; and that is the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Every time I raise any matter involving the administration of Senator Button's portfolio, he conducts some personal attack on me. He conducted a personal attack on one of the honourable senators on this side when he accused her of being a particular size. What relevance did that have to the debate? That is the sort of personal abuse to which Labor senators always degenerate whenever they get involved in this sort of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that your side does not descend to personal abuse?

—The honourable senator can say that I am personally denigrating Labor senators. I am not pointing to them one by one; I am saying that as a rule during debates in this chamber when the Labor Party is under attack Labor senators turn to engaging in personal abuse of senators on this side of the chamber because we have the audacity to question something that the Government has done. Senator Button made two points in relation to me. He made an attack on me in relation to the Solicitor-General's opinion. He accused me of something which I deny. He also made an attack on me in relation to my allegedly constantly opposing wage rises. That is absolutely and totally irrelevant to the debate, and it is totally untrue. When I interjected to that effect, Senator Button then said that the Opposition always opposes wage rises. He said that because he knew that I had caught him out on his personal attack on me. Government senators directed personal abuse at honourable senators on this side of the chamber about their physical characteristics or their manner of speaking, but did not apply their minds to the subject matter of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: From Senator Cook we heard nothing but bluster and personal attacks on everyone of those who spoke in the debate from this side of the chamber. The only arguments we heard from Government senators in support of their colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett-Senator Cook made this comment as the last speaker from the Government's side-was that the provider numbers protected the security of the doctor and the patient. In fact, the provider numbers are the means by which the doctors and the patients are identified. Senator Cook said that on the face of it when one looks at the number the first time one cannot tell those things. Of course, there is a code. It did not take Mr Gear very long to break the code.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not know the code.
—Senator Cook interjects that Mr Gear did not know the code. Maybe he did not know the code, but it did not take him very long to break the code because he was able--
—Every time you get a doctor's bill it has the code on it.

—As Senator Messner says, every time one receives a doctor's bill it has the provider number on it. That is the first thing that enables one to break the code. I come back to the point I was making. It did not take Mr Gear long to break the code in a certain respect, because he was able to go to New South Wales and claim that doctors in New South Wales were overcharging to the extent of some millions of dollars. So, in the first breakdown, he was very quickly able to identify New South Wales doctors. I presume that he also went to the other States. Senator Cook said something along the lines that all Mr Gear did was to point out that doctors in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory were overcharging by certain amounts of money. So he was immediately able to identify those doctors in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory.
—I raise a point of order. That is just absolutely wrong. I never said that.
—Order! No point of order is involved.

—Anyone who examines the code and notices that doctors' provider numbers are being repeated is able to identify the doctors. It only requires the code to be leaked somewhere along the line for computer operators who want that information to have ready access to it. I think Senator McLean interjected to that effect at one stage. I say to Senator Cook, `Yes, on the face of it, one is unable to identify the number, but it is only one step down the track before one will be able to identify the doctors and the patients'. But, again, that is just one specific example.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me also turn to the other defence which was taken by Senator Button of his colleague Dr Blewett. That was the claim that Dr Blewett was not personally responsible for the actions of his own staff within his own office. What a defence! When the Australian Labor Party was in opposition it claimed that Senator Durack, as the Attorney-General, was personally responsible because some officer of the Attorney-General's Department in an office in Perth, 3,000 miles away from Canberra, had in his bottom drawer a file which he had found too hard to handle, so he had sat on it for a number of years. Because that officer was sitting on this file for some time, the Australian Labor Party said that Senator Durack, as Attorney-General, was personally responsible for the actions of that officer and should have been sacked as Attorney-General. That was the standard which it wanted the Parliament to adopt when it was in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It looks different from the other side.

—It is different now that the Labor Party is in government. The Government says that Dr Blewett is not personally responsible for the actions of his personal staff working in his own office in Canberra. What absolute nonsense! The Solicitor-General, in his report, makes what I believe to be an absolutely facetious point along the lines that Dr Blewett could not be responsible for doing this because he is not allowed to be responsible for it under the Act. He is not allowed to do it under the Act, so he could not be responsible for doing it under the Act. That is the sort of argument that the Solicitor-General has raised to try to get this Government off the hook in this particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come back and just say, as I said before, that Senator Puplick, Senator Haines and I have pointed out altogether about nine or 10 occasions when confidential information about Australian citizens has been leaked by this Minister, by his staff, for whom he is personally responsible, or by officers of the Health Insurance Commission, which is a body operating within his responsibility. Therefore, on about nine or 10 occasions that the Opposition is able to identify, very close, important personal information has been leaked or released in some way either to newspapers or to the police, for instance about the women who had had terminations of their pregnancies and the prosecution of that doctor, all of which was confidential information. When will it stop? When will Dr Blewett and his staff and the Health Insurance Commission stop leaking this information? It is being leaked for crass political purposes.

In this case it has been leaked to denigrate the medical profession. That is what it is all about-to denigrate the medical profession, in order to prop up this failing Medicare service. But there are other cases, and there have been other crass political reasons why the information has been leaked for some reason or other. That office over there leaks like a sieve and, as I said in my earlier remarks, that rotten apple in the barrel is making a number of us on the Opposition side wonder how one can accept anything that any Minister says in this Parliament. After all, if a Minister today in the course of a debate gives an undertaking that he will provide some information or he will do something, then it may very well be that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will change the portfolios tomorrow. If Dr Blewett is given responsibility for that portfolio, how could one rely on what would happen? One cannot rely on anything that Dr Blewett is saying or doing. The apple is rotten and the Prime Minister should be dealing with it.

Again I come back to the personal situation of Dr Blewett because he is such a terrible example of what this Government has done to the privacy of the people of Australia. It is the Prime Minister's responsibility to pull Dr Blewett into line and sack him. But at least he should have been pulled into line some months ago. All of these matters should have been brought to his attention and he should have been told that the rights of the citizens of Australia to their privacy are absolutely utmost and must be contained within the confidential confines of the particular office within the Health Insurance Commission.

The Opposition believes that the Government now is getting far too much information about the private concerns of the citizens of Australia-I draw attention to the wealth inquiry which the Government is about to conduct-and the Opposition is desperately concerned that the Government will not keep that information confidential. The Opposition is endeavouring to block the Government's opportunities of getting the information. It condemns the Government not about hypothetical cases but real instances where the Government has caused harm to individuals by failing to protect their privacy, and I move, as I have said, that the Government be condemned for its failure to so protect their privacy.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Powell, proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure the survival of the ABC as an independent national broadcasting service, separate from SBS, and free from corporate or government interference, by providing adequate and long-term financial support; and the need for the Government to acknowledge that the ABC's role is more important now than it has ever been because of the dramatic concentration of the ownership of all sectors of the Australian media over the last 2 years.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There could scarcely be a matter of greater public importance at this time in Australia's history and more in the interests of Australia's democracy than the subject matter of this matter of public importance. Let me make it clear, however, that what I am talking about today is an independent Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). What the Australian Democrats are interested in is preserving the quality and integrity of our national broadcaster in the interests of the community. We are not involved in a campaign which is based on the ABC's own corporate interests. That is a very important point to make at the beginning of this debate. I draw the attention of the Senate to the statement of purpose which appears at the very beginning of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's fourth annual report which was tabled in this Parliament last week and which, because of various reasons, has not had as yet an adequate airing in this chamber. The statement of purpose begins:

SPEECH.PARA: As Australia's national broadcaster and major cultural organisation, the central objective of the ABC is to extend the range of ideas and experiences available to Australians and contribute to the development of values within the community and a sense of national purpose and identity.

Following that general statement a range of specifics is outlined. I would like to refer to a few of them. The report states that the ABC will strive to be a valued and vital part of Australian life, that it will explore major contemporary social, economic and political issues as well as developments in science, technology, education, philosophy and religion, that it will maintain its integrity and independence and strive for leadership in the Australian broadcasting system in the provision of high quality, innovative services and provide Australians with the best and most reliable coverage and analysis of events in Australia and abroad.

There are other points in the statement of purpose but I think those particular points are worth reiterating at this time. Where is the ABC at this time in relation to its ability to carry out those aims and objectives and to achieve its purpose as stated? Perhaps the trigger for the concern which is now being expressed in the Senate today and in the wider community was the becoming public of the proposal of the Department of Finance to cut the funding of the ABC this year by a further $19m. We then got into the annual brawl with the razor gang-I might say that governments of either colour have razor gangs-which the ABC has to undergo every year. Over the past two years the funding for the ABC has dropped by close to $50m. This annual brawl has now become a twice-yearly exercise as we are faced every year with mini-Budgets and maxi-Budgets. It is a very debilitating exercise for our national broadcaster, for an organisation which has the goals and the responsibilities which the ABC has. The Australian Democrats have called for long-term funding for the ABC. We believe the ABC should be funded on a five-year basis so that it can plan ahead. That is essential.

I point out that, even under the current unsatisfactory situation with the annual brawl with razor gangs, the ABC is doing a good job. Australians are getting a better deal for their ABC dollar. In the past year staffing levels have been reduced by 8 per cent, yet television transmission hours have increased by 12 per cent, Australian content on television has increased by 5 per cent and television repeats have been reduced by 6 per cent. The ABC has transferred $6m from salaries and expenses to fund a 300 per cent increase in ABC-made drama. The goal, which looks like being achieved, is 100 hours of ABC produced drama by the end of 1988. The increased activity in Australian drama content is important in relation to the problems the Australian film industry is experiencing. As this activity is increased and encouraged, that will be of advantage to the beleaguered Australian film industry.

The ABC has generally maintained its on-air services despite this 5 per cent real cut in funding. I highlight that the ABC has the highest rating for children's viewing. This is not surprising: there is a long and fine tradition of programming on the ABC for children of all ages and that is improving all the time. Many honourable senators, and perhaps even listeners, will not know that the television program Behind the News, which is shown during the day, has between one million and two million viewers each week. It is a highly valued program, particularly in the schools. In my own family I have found that it has been of great benefit in interesting young primary school children in what is going on in their world. Without such ABC programs we would all be the poorer.

There is considerable choice and diversity in prime time programming on the ABC. In the 6 to 10 p.m. slot the ABC puts on a range of programming: 34 per cent of drama of a range of varieties; 37 per cent of news, current affairs and documentaries; 10 per cent of arts, information and religious programs; and 12 per cent of light entertainment. If we compare that spread with what appears on commercial television stations during that prime time period we see that 55 per cent of commercial television is taken up with drama; 30 per cent with news; 0.5 per cent with arts and information; and 5.5 per cent with light entertainment. That demonstrates the diversity of programming provided to Australian television viewers by the ABC in spite of its straitened circumstances and the uncertainties of annual budgeting which it faces.

The ABC also has a clear record in other areas. I have mentioned children's programming in terms of its viewing audience; in terms of time, 23.5 per cent of the total transmission time is children's programming. On the commercial stations the figure is 15 per cent. In education, arts and religious programming the ABC figure is 22.6 per cent of time, compared with 2.5 per cent on the commercial stations, and they show no education programs at all. Twelve per cent of ABC transmissions are drama programs compared with 40 per cent on the commercial stations. So obviously the ABC offers programming on television in an area which is not provided by the commercial stations. Of course that is one of the major features and major expectations of the ABC by its supporters in the community, its viewers and its listeners.

The ABC also breaks new ground in programming. It is often in the forefront. Many of the new programs of the ABC are taken up by the commercial stations. The excellent Towards 2000 program, the Gillies Report, Mother and Son, A Big Country and so on are just some of them. It is interesting to note that even in quiz programs a different approach is taken. ABC quiz programs do not rely on big prizes, big money or any of those gimmicks for their appeal, and their appeal is often considerable. Perhaps most of my emphasis has been on television: let us not forget radio. Radio National, as we know, has a very dedicated and devoted audience.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was before Parliament.

—Or it had before the parliamentary broadcasts were imposed upon it. ABC FM and the metropolitan and regional radio stations all provide strong news and information bases and programming of specialist kinds for specialist audiences. All this has been provided, as I said, in the current climate where there is the knife edge of annual funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Another reason for long term funding is that it would provide the ABC with an increased ability to be genuinely independent of any government or managerial editorial influence. I shall give an instance to point out what I mean by this. All over Australia now, particularly since we have had a Federal Labor government and State Labor governments, there are groups whose role one would expect would be to analyse and criticise government performance in their interest area and on behalf of a specific clientele. Such groups are now very often receiving funding from government. In most instances the Australian Democrats would support that. But one of the unfortunate consequences of this type of annual funding can be, it seems to me, that often such organisations feel themselves hamstrung in their purpose of critique and analysis of government action and policies by that funding structure, especially approaching Budget time when sometimes the silence is practically deafening. I sympathise with such organisations but it is a problem and can be a problem and I think it must definitely be removed from our national broadcaster from which we expect independence and integrity. Given the critical importance of the ABC as an independent voice and its own statement of purpose with which I began this speech, it is important that the ABC does not have to run repeatedly to government cap in hand and feel itself constrained or pressured in any way in terms of that very independence which in general terms most people would agree we want to sustain at all costs.

The question of achieving increased funding for the ABC has arisen, and proposals for advertising or corporate sponsorship have been floated. I suppose that we must look at those proposals and answer the question: Why not? I will be interested, in the course of this debate, to see whether we can ascertain the position of the Opposition in this matter. I have looked at the comments that Senator Messner made in addressing the ABC annual report. He has called on the Government to make a firm statement with regard to these options. I certainly endorse that call. Senator Messner, however, also said, `There are many options'. I suggest that we must close off the option of advertising or sponsorship for the ABC. We need to give the ABC adequate and long term funding so that it can carry out its role with some security and with considerable support.

I move to another Liberal Party voice on this issue. Mr Ian Macphee has pointed out to us this week, in an article in the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, that in his view there is no way that the Government would now contemplate a gold tax, given Mr Alan Bond's extensive media holdings. I contend that that applies not just to this Government but also to the Liberal Party. Mr Bond owns a significant television network. Let us imagine this situation applied to the ABC and that the ABC has to undertake sponsorship in quarantined areas, specific areas, such as its orchestras. If the Benson and Hedges company sponsored the ABC orchestras, would the ABC then hesitate to screen a non-sponsored, hard-hitting anti-smoking documentary?

We really must address this issue. We must recognise that it is not possible to quarantine areas of an integrated operation such as this; that the core areas and the non-core areas are, and will remain, inextricably linked. I think the Public Broadcasting Service in the United States of America provides a salutary lesson in this regard. It is a fact of life that whoever holds the purse strings holds the power. This is why the Australian Democrats are disturbed by the proposals for sponsorship of the ABC. It is also, incidentally, why the Democrats are disturbed by the ALP accepting $10,000 from Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd. As I said, whoever holds the purse strings holds the power.

Commercial stations have to please the majority and, to the extent that the ABC became a commercial operator, it would be forced more and more to please the majority. Commercial operations cannot cater for a minority market. That is accepted. Special interest groups would lose out in the event that the ABC was in any way dependent upon sponsorship of any kind. At the moment special interests can be met on the ABC in a fairly random way. We can move from a program on consumer protection to one on jazz to one for antique lovers. It is the case that we will not get all Australians, or even the majority of Australians, listening to or watching the ABC at once, but at some time there will be something there for all Australians.

On an extremely practical note, the question of sponsorship, of advertising, for the ABC must also take into account the question of the advertising dollar. It is interesting that the television networks were reported in the Australian Financial Review this morning to be very concerned about this, and they should be. As all of the evidence has shown, the advertising dollar is static. This was identified during the deliberations of the Senate Select Committee on Television Equalisation. It is clear that a very flat plateau has been reached and that it will be very difficult for large sums of money to be gathered, particularly for the ABC which, as I have said, does not appeal to a majority audience and ratings not having been a significant factor, therefore, in the past. In a practical way, this question of sponsorship for the ABC raises its own problems. It is certainly not a way out. As I said, there are other ways out which should be taken.

The matter of public importance that we have raised here today goes on to emphasise the fact that an ABC which is independent and which can maintain its integrity is even more important now than it has ever been. We have experienced over the last couple of years, and are still experiencing, quite dramatic contractions in the ownership of all aspects of our media. Over 60 per cent of our newspapers are owned by one proprietor, Rupert Murdoch, in one way or another, and success for the current Maxwell bid would tie up the vast majority of our newspapers in the hands of overseas interests. It is disturbing to see that the entrenched views of Mr Keating are firm against any action to prevent that sort of overseas ownership. We have three commercial television networks. The commercial television world is now divided into three blocks. Kerry Packer has a virtual monopoly in the magazine area, especially that of women's magazines. It is interesting to note that just recently in France the Pearson group takeover of a major newspaper has been refused on the ground that Murdoch, a non-European, owns a significant share of that company-above 20 per cent at this point. There are also fewer newspapers in Australia. Two major newspapers have gone and another one is on the slide in Sydney; so the choice is narrowed even further.

The ABC is important, and it does have its burdens. One of those burdens is its annual battle with government. I have suggested a way out of that. Another burden is the need for it to cater to all minority interests. A further burden is the parliamentary broadcast in respect of which it has a statutory need to fulfil. We believe that there should be a separate network for that. While the current ABC campaign is emphasising its independence, quite rightly and of necessity, given the threat to its continuation as an independent voice, this does not mean that significant structural changes are not needed. But we cannot expect everything in the face of the instability of annual funding and funding cuts, actual and threatened. As I stated in my letter to the President, it is more crucial now than ever, in the face of media concentration, for the ABC to remain a quality broadcaster of integrity and independence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that we are debating today concerning the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is timely in some respects and not so timely in others. It is timely because tonight a meeting is to be held at the Sydney Town Hall, ostensibly organised by the New South Wales Advisory Council of the ABC and the Friends of the ABC. At that meeting a number of speakers-many of them people of some prominence in our community-will outline their concerns and tell us why more should be done for the ABC and why the Government should improve its contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the fundamental problem with the meeting that is to be held tonight I think characterises the difficulty in the debate that has been carried on in recent weeks about ABC funding. The claim that the meeting is being organised by the New South Wales Advisory Council of the ABC and the Friends of the ABC simply is not true. It has been made to give the impression that ABC management is at least at arm's length from this meeting. But today I received some information which I think gives the lie to this. Huw Evans, who has been very prominent on the ABC, even on the quiz shows that Senator Powell mentioned, was telephoned and asked whether he would accept an invitation to speak at this meeting. He was asked by a person from ABC corporate affairs-hardly at arm's length from ABC management. Mr Evans replied that he was happy to speak at the meeting but he would have to exercise his right to offer some criticisms of the ABC. The person replied that that was fine with the ABC, and that was the end of the conversation. However, that person rang back the next day to say that the invitation had been withdrawn, the difficulty being that ABC management, which is very happy to have this debate conducted in the public arena, was not happy at all for anyone to be given an opportunity to go to the meeting tonight and perhaps put a contrary view. No matter how minor the differences might have been, ABC management was determined to keep hold of the reins, to make sure that no other point of view could be put. Later in my contribution I shall outline another example of that.

As I said, Senator Powell's motion is in that respect at least timely. It is timed to coincide with the campaign. But where it is not timely, where it is premature, is that it is widely known-it is hardly a great secret-that Senator Gareth Evans, the responsible Minister, will be releasing a major series of discussion papers on Friday of this week. Those discussion papers will go to the heart of the issues that Senator Powell has raised today and other issues concerning the ABC. The very reason that Senator Evans is not here today speaking in this debate is that he is presently in Sydney discussing these issues with the boards of the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). The difficulty we have is that it is just not going to be possible, in a debate like this, the pre-empt the release of those papers. Therefore I would have thought that to interrupt the discussions that Senator Evans is having today is something we could not do, and that is why I had hoped that Senator Powell could have waited a little longer. Nonetheless, I want to say on behalf of the Government that we remain committed to a strong national broadcasting sector.

The discussion papers that will be released on Friday are squarely aimed at precisely what this matter of public importance calls for-ensuring the long term viability of an independent, vibrant, relevant and viable ABC. There is no question of any assault of the kind which has been suggested. The Government is trying to concentrate on what it is that makes the ABC the institution that is worth funding. We are concentrating on what the ABC's objectives are. We are focusing on what the objectives should be. It would seem to me, from speaking to many people at the ABC, that that is a concern not only of the Government but also of many people at the ABC itself. We are talking about the pursuit of excellence and the setting, not the following, of standards, and the filling of gaps so that we can cater for special minorities that might otherwise not be catered for. We are also not catering, one hopes, just for an intellectual elite, but rather making sure that there are programs for all of the people at least some of the time.

Having identified what the special characteristics of the ABC might be, the Government now wants to work out a way of guaranteeing funding for the future so that we are not confronted with this annual sordid haggle over the ABC's budgetary position. Instead, the Government wants certainty, it wants some planning and integrity put into the Budget process, so that not only does the Government know where the ABC is going, but the ABC itself will get some idea. Senator Evans has deliberately refrained over the last few weeks and months from responding in detail to the barrage of rumours that we have heard, many of them, I might say, distortions of the future of the ABC and the SBS. I think he has corrected some erroneous financial assertions that have been made, but otherwise he has been happy to let all those distortions lie on the table because he and the Government propose that these matters should be exhaustively debated once those papers have been released. That process will go on for some time. There will be no decision on the future of the ABC until after there has been a proper period of consultation, debate and discussion not just with the ABC but with the community at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —So they are not policy statements at all.

—They are issues papers; they will canvass the issues. The Government is not proposing to set the policy by the issuing of the papers, rather to put down a framework for the debate. There is no Government proposal to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS. That is not a highly original statement. I thought the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had made it clear that this would never happen unless there was agreement with the ethnic communities. Whilst I have not checked with the ethnic communities in recent times, given the pretty obvious expressions of discontent and dislike for that proposal when it was first mooted some time back, I would think that the Prime Minister's promise, as indeed with all of his promises, holds firm. There will be no amalgamation of the ABC and the SBS.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been much talk recently about the ABC suffering death by a thousand cuts. We have heard all about these slashes in the forward estimates. I only wish that some people would look at the forward estimates of my Department. There would be a few people crying there as well. It is worth noting, if we want to put some factual basis to this debate, that as a proportion of total Budget outlays the 1987-88 appropriation of $430.4m-and that excludes approximately $70m which was a cost to the Government of installing and maintaining ABC transmitters-was 0.55 per cent. That is slightly above the average level of funding for the ABC for the past decade, which has been 0.549 per cent. ABC funding has grown substantially-by 10.7 per cent in real terms-during the five years of the Hawke Government. The Hawke Government has nothing to be ashamed of when it comes to funding for the ABC. To the extent that the ABC's overall funding position has declined, and I might say only by a fraction in the last two years, it should be remembered that there has been considerable pressure on the budgets of all publicly funded bodies, and all Ministers know well the extent of that pressure. The slight real decrease in ABC appropriations since 1985-86 is primarily due to the fact that during 1985-86 there were some extraordinary and large capital items. They included $18.4m for satellite transponder leasing, $10.5m for plant and equipment associated with the second regional radio network and satellite facilities, and $10.9m for property initiatives. So we cannot use 1985-86 as a base year; it simply was not. There were all of these extra capital items in the ABC's budget of that year. The ABC in fact has not fared badly at all, particularly if one takes it in the context of the discipline that has been extended over the whole of the Government as far as spending goes in recent years.

As to Mr Hill's claim that the Department of Finance forward estimates show that the Government intends to slash the ABC budget by $19m this year, and that this has been recommended by the Department of Finance, I think we should understand that all that forward estimates represent is nothing more than a statement of the existing financial position applying certain mechanical financial rules. They are not necessarily a reliable guide to the eventual outcome. Approximately $16m of the forward estimates reduction represents the completion of ABC capital projects. As with any publicly funded body, appropriations are not made to cover projects which no longer exist. New capital appropriations will no doubt be sought to replace those I have just mentioned, the completed projects. There is no reason to assume that the Expenditure Review Committee (ERC) or the Cabinet will not in the end support at least some of those. It is not possible to say now how many, but quite obviously Senator Evans will be going forward with submissions to have more capital projects funded in the Budget. I have no doubt, given the eloquence and persuasiveness of his arguments, as is so often seen by all honourable senators in this place, that he will be successful.

Only $2.8m of the forward estimates figures pertain to the ABC's operational and administrative expenses. That figure represents 0.7 per cent of the total budget. Again, it cannot be assumed that that will be the final outcome. The Budget process has only just begun. I think that the ERC has only begun to meet in the last few days, so we are a long way from seeing what final decisions might be made. I think we should have a bit of patience.

The Government does not want to see the ABC shrink. We will continue to support it. The ABC will not have any difficulty in persuading the rest of the Government about funding if it can demonstrate to the public that the public gets value for its money. If the ABC can produce programming excellence, professional broadcasting, authoritative news and current affairs and no shoddy or tacky programs, it will have no trouble in persuading the community that $500m worth of its hard earned tax money is being well spent. There has been no trouble or little trouble in persuading the community in the past. I have no doubt that that will be the position in the future.

Senator Evans has already made it clear to the Chairman and to the Managing Director of the ABC that he is quite prepared to go in to bat for them in the forthcoming Budget process, both in respect of any new capital projects they might want and in respect of recurrent funding. Knowing the vigour with which he pursues those promises, I have no doubt that he will be successful. Mr Hill has been running a campaign that the Government has been secretly planning an attack on the ABC. On 22 February 1988 David Hill said:
The consideration of various options by the Department of Transport and Communications was conducted in secret and that is very troubling.

Senator Evans offered the ABC the opportunity to have an officer seconded full time to the departmental review process. That offer was declined last September. It is pretty rich for David Hill or anyone else to whinge about a secret process when they were invited into its very heart, into its bosom, and they declined the opportunity. The Chairman, Mr Somervaille, confirmed that in writing to Senator Evans. There has been no attempt to keep the ABC out of the process.

On the question of advertising, about which Senator Powell spoke at quite some length, Senator Evans has made it clear that it is not, and never has been, his view that the ABC should be dependent on advertising or corporate sponsorship for any of its mainstream activities. It is the Government's and the Parliament's responsibility to fund those mainstream activities. The Government has not walked, and will not walk, away from it. The Government has no specific policy proposals for advertising for any non-mainstream functions, but no doubt it would be prepared to consider any such proposals that might come from the ABC. I am disappointed at the campaign that has been waged by ABC management and the ABC Board on this question. I hope that the release of the discussion papers this Friday will bring an end to some of the paranoia about the Government's secret attacks and people will see that the Government is serious about maintaining a viable and independent ABC.

I would like to turn to the second part of the text of Senator Powell's matter of public importance which refers to the concentration of media ownership and the allegation that there has been a dramatic concentration. The central thrust of the Government's initiatives in media ownership has been to reduce the concentration. It has been more than successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not arguing with you about that.

—It was not long ago that those who owned newspapers could also hold significant television and radio interests in the same cities. Senator Powell says that she is not worried about that. I would have thought that, when it comes to looking at say, the Fairfax organisation in Sydney--
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. The Minister said that I interjected to say that I was not concerned about cross-media ownership. What I said was that--
—On a point of order; if the honourable senator is claiming to be misrepresented, the appropriate time to claim that misrepresentation is at the conclusion of the debate and not during it.
—I was about to point that out.

—If I have misheard the honourable senator and done her an injustice, I apologise. However, I would have thought that there should have been sufficient concern about, for example, the Fairfax organisation being able to own, in Sydney and Melbourne, newspapers and television stations plus a plethora of radio stations, so that all of the media arms were owned by the one person. I would have thought that any government that could introduce a system that did away with that ought to be praised rather than criticised. The reality is that that situation had existed ever since television was introduced. The developments in communications over the last 30 years have been so great that it was well and truly time for a change. That is what we have done. The strict cross-ownership rules embracing newspapers, television and radio are unprecedented. They have wide support throughout the community and the Government stands by them. If anything, we will improve them and make them better.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, there used to be only four major Australian media players-that is, News Ltd, Fairfax, Packer and the Herald and Weekly Times-which dominated newspapers, radio and television. There are now nine major players. That increase from four to nine hardly represents more concentration. In newspapers there is Fairfax and News Ltd, as well as a number of smaller owners. In television there is Northern Star Holdings Ltd, Qintex Ltd and the Bond Corporation. They control the major metropolitan networks. I suppose one could also say that the Ramsay group now controls a significant number of the regional stations. As well as that, who knows how many owners of the radio stations there are. I would have thought that, once again, the figures demonstrate just how serious the Government has been in its commitment. The rationalisation of commercial broadcasting ownership, produced by the reform package, prevents any owner from holding more than one licence in a market. Time and time again the Government has demonstrated its commitment and the runs are on the board in so far as legislation in this place is concerned. The former two-station rule in television-which had become such a farce that it equated two stations in, say, Kalgoorlie and Rockhampton with two stations in Sydney and Melbourne-was long overdue for change. The Government moved, and moved swiftly.

In summary, the Government will continue to support the ABC rather than attack it. We want to make sure, however, that it has a defined role with which the ABC, the community and, obviously, the Government will be happy. We want to make sure it remains viable, independent and relevant. In so far as media concentration is concerned, the Government's record is excellent. We propose to continue working in the same directions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties welcome the opportunity to discuss the future of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). We seldom have the opportunity to discuss issues in this kind of depth. However, I am terribly disappointed at the way in which the Australian Democrats have chosen to phrase this proposal that is before us today. They have spoken of little more than motherhood-type things and certainly give us no real indication of their own thinking as to how they might seek to solve the very significant problems which the ABC faces. Quite clearly, Senator Powell abdicated her responsibility in this regard in the course of her remarks. She found no positive things to say about how funding might be reorganised or rearranged to justify her conclusion that inadequate funding is being made available. I would like to hear her solutions, but it seems that we will wait a long time for that to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: In my opening remarks I note with a great deal of disappointment-I am sure it will be a disappointment as far as the rest of the community is concerned too-that we now learn that the much-awaited statements and papers to be brought down by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) on Friday with respect to the future funding of the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service are nothing more than discussion papers. In fact, the Government has no firm policy, apparently, as to what it intends in this area. That means that in the period leading up to the Budget we will be wallowing in cross-currents of various ideas, suggestions and what have you-all of which, I might add, are well-known in the community already and are being discussed widely. But those ideas and suggestions will not be positive decisions of the Government and consequently the people who are trying to manage the ABC will be in no better position to know what the future holds for them than they are at the current time.

I want to make the Liberal and National parties' position on the future of the ABC absolutely clear. We are committed to the maintenance of an independent organisation that provides quality and reliable services for what might be regarded as minority groups in the community. There is no doubt that the ABC has provided in the past a great deal of service to those living in remote areas, to those interested in the arts and to those who receive from the ABC information in such a form as to provide, for example, educational opportunities. Of course we know of the ABC's maintenance of the great institutions such as the symphony orchestras in the various cities which tour around the whole country to provide musical entertainment for the whole of the Australian community. We also know of the great commitment to Radio Australia, which is a vital outward-reaching instrument for Australia's foreign development and the gaining of a better Australian image in the world. We hear everywhere we travel overseas of the way in which Radio Australia is received and how well regarded it really is. Certainly that commitment I have just expressed is backed up by the past record of Liberal-National Party governments. We ensured that adequate funding was made available to the ABC when we were in government.

It is timely, though, to relate the total expenditure of the ABC to the expenditure of the commercial broadcasters. A pattern emerges which shows a very significant change. The expenditure of the ABC, for both radio and television, was equivalent in 1979-80 to 33.5 per cent of the expenditure of the commercial operators, but in 1987-88 that figure dropped to 26.4 per cent. It is projected that that figure will drop even further in the next three or four years, so that by 1991 it will reach 17 per cent-roughly half the figure of a decade earlier. That is significant. It indicates that there is a crisis in ABC funding because, relative to the expenditure of other broadcasters, it is falling behind. Some solution, apart from the traditional ones, has to be found. We know that the ABC is trying. We have seen Mr Hill on television debating with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) the things that have been undertaken, and we recall that he has pointed out that staff numbers have been reduced by 600. We note also that many staff have been put onto contracts, and that must be a step forward. We know, too, that there have been changes in the way in which certain people employed by the ABC in specialist capacities have been put onto longer run contracts. I think those things augur well for a more flexible future for the ABC, so that there will be better opportunities for reorganising staff and making sure that the Corporation's capacity to move with the times is kept up to its optimum level. Quite clearly, that is necessary in the light of the figures I have just read out which show that the ABC is falling behind the commercial operators.

We note, too, that the ABC is committed to doing certain things which commercial operators do not have to do. For instance, 23.5 per cent of the ABC's total transmission time is devoted to children's programming, compared with the figure for commercial operators of only 15 per cent. We find, too, that 22.6 per cent of the ABC's time goes on religious, education and arts programs, compared with the 2.5 per cent of the commercial networks. These community obligations which the ABC is forced to undertake are of great importance to the future of Australian culture.

I suppose that one of the most significant things occurring as far as the ABC is concerned is that in the latest financial year there has been a big increase in the amount of time, and therefore money, being committed by the ABC to Australian-made drama. That is now up to about 100 hours a year, and it has roughly trebled in the last year or two. That is surely a significant leap forward. That, by the way, compares with the obligation imposed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on commercial networks to devote some 104 hours per year to this purpose. So the ABC is indeed competing well on those grounds.

Perhaps the area in which changes are occurring most-and it is an area which gives many supporters of the Liberal and National parties cause for a great deal of concern-is the area of public affairs and news generally. That area has always been of great interest to the bulk of Australian people. The ABC has come to be relied upon as a great source of independent information. Yet in recent times political forces-both from the Left and perhaps some might say also the Right, particularly the right wing of the Labour Party in New South Wales-have caused us to worry about the independence of the ABC's programming. I believe these things must be addressed by the Commonwealth Government as part of the discussion process now to be undertaken.

We note, too, that the ABC has lost a number of its public affairs presenters and compilers to the commercial networks. We should observe that this cuts both ways. It means the ABC suffers from the loss of personnel in this area, but the commercial operators gain. Contrary to what Senator Powell asserted in the terms of her matter of public importance, that this concentration is leading to some kind of fixed view of the world being presented by commercial operators, it seems to me that the seeding of people from the ABC into commercial public affairs operation will work in reverse-it may well improve the standards of the commercial operators' public affairs programs. I know from my own contacts with commercial television operators that they are indeed spending a great deal of time and money committing themselves to new public affairs formats which will employ new talent and people who have come from other parts of the industry. That alone puts the lie to Senator Powell's suggestions that somehow our whole television and radio world is falling into a pit from which we will never be able to drag it. I believe the opposite is true: we are now seeing a brave new world develop in which the ABC itself will be forced into a position of involving itself in greater competition. I think that augurs well for all of us, particularly the ABC, in making sure that its programs do maintain that true independence in the political arena which we have been worrying about now for some time.

I believe that Senator Richardson, in his remarks, has done us a disservice in that he has not got his figures right in all circumstances. For instance, he spoke about the cuts in expenditure and of capital commitments, particularly mentioning the transponders on the satellites. That is not a one off thing. The fact is that it is an ongoing expense. It is not something that is suddenly just wiped off the cost structure of the ABC. That is an incorrect statement for him to rely on.

But the big problem that the ABC faces and where the future threat to it lies is the fact that it already has a shortage of $120m of capital expenditure for its maintenance program just to upgrade obsolete equipment. That is without looking more broadly at the expansion of ABC networks or of new services that might be introduced. If we take that figure into account the capital demand for the ABC in the future is something like $400m. That is where the real problem lies in the future. I hope the Government will be in a position to help us understand this problem better as a result of the release of the discussion papers on Friday.

Senator Powell has spoken at some length about her problems with the ideas of advertising, both for SBS and for the ABC. It remains to be seen exactly what the Government is suggesting in this regard. We have certainly seen some leaks in the newspapers in recent days that lead us to conclude that this is about to happen. However, we have to wait and see whether they are the suggestions which will emanate from the Government. I believe that there is some room for movement in regard to corporate sponsorship, the orchestras and some phases of the operations of the ABC. They are things that we ought to be examining if we have an eye to the future. Those things should not be dropped on the sidelines. However, it is election time in New South Wales. These things are likely to raise their heads in the weeks and months ahead. We read back in September in the Times on Sunday that the Government had not given up the idea of merger of the ABC with the SBS which it denied with great haste before the July election. That must still be on the agenda. Nevertheless, because it is election time we find that Barrie Unsworth is pleading with Hawke not to proceed with any merger of the SBS with the ABC and, consequently, we can see that becoming an issue during the election campaign in the next few days.

I reiterate that the Liberal and National parties are committed to an independent radio and television network to be operated by the ABC. We want to see those services improve. We believe that there is an exciting future for the ABC. We want to be part of it and we want to encourage it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up a sense which I gathered from Senator Richardson lay behind his early remarks; that is a sense of support for the corporate managers of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I do not think Senator Powell's matter of public importance in any way suggests that that is really what the Australian Democrats are on about. We are on about protecting the ABC as that body perceived by the very large number of Australians who enjoy, listen to and watch the ABC. Thousands of people have turned out over recent years for meetings on the ABC. I point out to Senator Richardson that at the meeting in Queensland, no matter who organised the meeting, some 2,000 people turned up. The perception that those people have of the ABC is of an organisation that provides high quality programs in a wide range of areas which are not being provided by any other medium in Australia at this time. We are certainly not supporting the corporate structure of the ABC however it might be behaving in helping to organise the venues and other details of these meetings. We are supporting people such as Andrew Olle, Huw Evans-whom Senator Richardson has already mentioned-Matt Peacock, Robyn Williams, Norman Swan, Wendy Bacon, Caroline Jones and John Pilger. They are people who have been prepared to stand up and be counted on a very wide range of issues and, very often, against the forces of internal management.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to mention one aspect which bore this out and that was the interview between the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and John Pilger last year on the ABC. In my view John Pilger asked the Prime Minister a number of relevant and important questions. Not only did he not get proper answers, he got a very poor response from both the Prime Minister and from ABC management.

TALK.START.PARA: —He admitted that he edited the answers.
—The answers which were given were relevant to the information which was not being given by the other media in Australia.
—In the highly unlikely event that anyone ever interviews you, you will find it is not nice when they edit the answers.

—That has happened to me very often by the commercial media because they do not like some of the things that I say. I will get on to that in a minute. The importance of the ABC lies very largely in the preservation of freedom in this country. We live in an information age; we live in an age in which the possession and control of the flow of information is vital to the protection of freedom. We also live in an age-I will pick up on what Senator Messner was saying about corporate sponsorship here-in which what passes for information, namely, large amounts of what goes by in the commercial media and what goes by in the form of advertising, swamps that which is vital and which really matters and it is very hard for the ordinary citizen to pick up what is relevant and what is important for him and for her. The ABC, by not being involved in this form of dilution-in which the commercial media are involved, plays a very important role.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like briefly to mention some of the really excellent programs which the ABC runs. All honourable senators would be aware of them, but I think it is interesting when one makes a list of them to see just how much we have come to rely on the ABC. The ABC's Science Unit is generally recognised around the world as the most important public radio science unit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reckon Rock Arena is better.

—The honourable senator may well do. It is a very interesting remark that he regards Rock Arena as more important than the function of the ABC Science Unit. I hope that those people who listen to the rest of this debate will take that into account when they hear whatever silly remarks the honourable senator will continue to make during this debate. The Science Unit has, for years, run the Science Show with Robyn Williams. Again one of the very best and highest quality science broadcasters in the world and generally recognised as such. Occam's Razor, for example, has been running for a number of years and there are programs such as Quantum and Earthworm. The Opposition would be interested to know that recently Peter Hunt ran a program which exposed the way in which the Labor Government in Western Australia had suppressed very important and very relevant environmental information because it was information that that Government did not want to hear. These are the sorts of things that the ABC has been doing. In the rural and general area there are programs such as Countrywide and the Country Hour on radio.

SPEECH.PARA: In the consumer area, the ABC has The Investigators, which is the sort of program that one does not see and would not see on commercial television. I refer also to The Women's Program. I am sorry that Senator Stone is not in the chamber to hear me say that I support The Coming Out Show. I think it has played an extremely useful part in raising issues that are relevant to women and in drawing attention to the way in which women and people generally in our society have functioned and may function under different conditions. I refer to the overseas news and in-depth analysis programs such as Indian Pacific and The Europeans that we have seen in recent years.

The ABC's literature programs include The Science Bookshop and First Edition which deal with the publication of new books. Often I have picked up a publication that has been discussed on those programs before I have seen it in the bookshops. I refer to the serious drama programs screened by the ABC-not only Australian drama but excellent series from overseas such as I, Claudius, Family at War, The Forsythe Saga. One gets intellectual humour on the ABC that one does not find on the commercial stations. I refer to programs such as The Good Life, which dealt with a very interesting situation in a humorous way and which brought out many of the conflicts and difficulties in living an alternative lifestyle. The program Steptoe and Son brought out the pathos of elderly people in a depressed situation.

As Senator Powell has mentioned, one sees the occasional religious program on commercial television, but they are straight presentations of church services. One does not get on commercial television the in-depth discussion of comparative religions and religion at work in various countries that one gets on the ABC. The various State orchestras have been mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you like all the programs on the ABC?

—It is interesting that Senator Schacht is attempting to run down the ABC during this debate. I shall listen to what he has to say with some interest. The ABC conducts simulcast broadcasts of opera, ballet and serious music. I am sure that Senator Schacht has never watched those programs because he has no interest in them. It seems that he would deny other people the opportunity to have that enjoyment and that uplifting experience. ABC FM consistently plays good music. My complaint is that one of the AM programs is no longer broadcasting good music; there is none on any of the commercial radio channels.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of investigative journalism we have the news, The 7.30 Report-I notice that many honourable senators watch that program in the dining room-and Four Corners. I shall list some of the programs which have led to major and important inquiries in this country. The Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct that is going on at present would not have occurred had the Four Corners program not investigated that matter. Another excellent program which was run on Four Corners concerned the neglect of surplus military aircraft.
