TALK.START.PARA: —The matter brought forward by Senator Powell draws attention to a number of matters in relation to the future of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I wish to comment on two of them. One is the evidence of government interference with the independence and programming independence of the ABC. The other is the role of the ABC in the light of what the matter from the Australian Democrats refers to as the dramatic concentration of the ownership of all sectors of the Australian media over the last two years.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn firstly to the question of the need for a national broadcaster to be kept free from government interference. Government interference with national broadcasters is not confined to totalitarian countries. Even an institution such as the British Broadcasting Corporation does not find itself from time to time able to resist the pressures put upon it by governments in that country. The ABC, I regret to say, not only has not been able to resist pressure put on it by the Government but indeed has taken some decisions at a managerial level which I believe have been designed to keep the Government off its back and, when Government pressure has been applied in certain areas, has been only too willing to buckle under.

I propose to cite three cases, each of them of fairly recent origin. The first, to which reference has already been made, is the question of the appointment of Wendy Bacon to a position in the ABC. It will be recalled that Wendy Bacon had established a reputation in the newspapers, in particular in the Times on Sunday and in its predecessor, the National Times, for what is colloquially called investigative journalism. Most of that journalism was devoted to exposing rackets, scandals and criminal behaviour touching directly upon the right wing of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in New South Wales and the whole sleazy web of mates and arrangements which have become a feature of the Government of New South Wales and which are shortly to be purged at the election on 19 March.

The way in which Wendy Bacon was treated was clearly an attempt by people in the ABC to ensure that there was not some potential further embarrassment for the ABC by having on staff somebody known to be hostile to, or at the very least known not to have been intimidated by, those in the Government who have close links with the ABC and close links, through the ABC, with all sorts of other elements. A report by Lyndall Crisp in the Times on Sunday on 3 January 1988 drew attention to the penchant Mr Hill has for hiring old ALP connections, a number of whom were named in the article. The article said in part:
The public debate on this issue-
that is, the appointment of Ms Bacon-

makes it apparent that Labor stalwarts such as Mr Hill, who is believed to have his eye on Canberra, will never forgive Ms Bacon for writing critical stories that expose weaknesses, great and small, in Labor heroes such as Lionel Murphy, Bob Hawke and Neville Wran.

Mr Hill decided that the best way to defend himself from this attack was to call into question Ms Bacon's suitability for the position. A report in the Adelaide Advertiser on 16 January 1988 says of Mr Hill:
He said that he had not been able to satisfy himself that Ms Bacon was fully qualified in terms of ability and experience for a position with the program.

That is absolute and arrant nonsense. The decision-a decision which I welcome and on which I congratulate the ABC-to appoint Trisha Goddard to the ABC quite clearly indicates that the question of whether a person has the ability, talent or experience is clearly very subjective. It does not necessarily derive from long experience in a particular format.

I make no secret of the fact that Trisha Goddard is a friend of mine. She has been a very good friend of mine since she first arrived in Australia. I was delighted with her appointment. But the point that it illustrates is this: in order to secure that sort of position with the ABC Mr Hill was quite prepared, on the one hand, to defend Ms Goddard's lack of experience as a presenter of those sorts of programs and, on the other hand, to say that that was grounds upon which Ms Bacon should be ruled out. That is simply not the reason Ms Bacon did not get the job. She did not get the job because the ABC had already been bullied and cowered by the Government into not appointing people who were regarded as unsympathetic to a particular faction within the Labor Party.

The second instance relates to a story which Alan Ramsey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 December 1987 in which he alleged that he had been told by the Prime Minister that `We don't fund the ABC to do programs on Peter Abeles', which implied quite clearly that the Prime Minister was anxious to see that the ABC did not pursue particular lines of inquiry or inquiry into particular individuals. Despite the calls by Senator Messner for an inquiry to be conducted into the basis of whether these allegation were correct, absolutely nothing has been done in that regard.

The third instance I raise is a rather wonderful one which I have had the pleasure of pursuing through Estimates committees-the question of why the ABC should not be allowed to broadcast a tape it has of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) giving a lecture at the Australian National Gallery. Mr Keating gave a lecture at the Australian National Gallery, described by Tony Stephens in the Sydney Morning Herald at some length. Mr John McDonald, the newspaper's art writer, examined the tape of Mr Keating's lecture which the ABC had made but which was being prevented from being broadcast. The article reads:
Mr McDonald said . . .
``The Treasurer made a good fist of his material-
it was a speech about neo-classical art-
presenting a competent crib of the art and philosophy of the period. It would have passed for the work of any group of undergraduates in a fine arts department.

The actual written text of Mr Keating's speech was made available when a Senate Estimates committee demanded that it be made available. A request to the ABC under the Freedom of Information Act for it had previously been rejected. Those who have heard the tape will say-indeed, this is the substance of the report carried in the Sydney Morning Herald-that the reason that the tape was not broadcast was that the Treasurer has what the Sydney Morning Herald report describes as a `haywire' method of pronunciation. It stated that names such as Brunelleschi, Greuze and David and the Oath of the Horatii were not able to be pronounced in a way which reflects adequately upon the competence of the Treasurer to divest himself of his massive knowledge of neo-classical art. It is a very sorry position to have arrived at for the ABC to be intimidated into not broadcasting what, after all, the Treasurer undoubtedly claims is a significant contribution to the intellectual life of this country in terms of information about neo-classical art.

I turn to the role of the ABC. I agree with a great deal of what has been said in terms of the significance of the specialist broadcasting of the ABC. Senator Coulter drew attention to the fact that the Opposition ought to listen to the Earthworm program, in particular the program that Peter Hunt did on the suppression of certain material by the Western Australian Government. If Senator Coulter had paid closer attention to the two parts of that he would have heard that I was interviewed at length on that program, so the Opposition is fully seized of the significance of Peter Hunt's report and indeed his praise of Occam's Razor is absolutely correct. I had the pleasure of giving at least one of the 15-minute talks on Occam's Razor and I have broadcast about 35 book reviews for the ABC Science Show as well as a large number of set pieces over the last couple of years. It is therefore very disturbing to see that in today's Sydney Morning Herald Robyn Williams is quoted as saying:
We are already a Third World broadcaster in terms of resources and manning compared with the BBC, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and the US public broadcasters.

He went on to describe the relative difficulties with which the ABC science unit has to contend. I entirely endorse the remarks Senator Coulter made about the significance of the ABC Science Show and equally leap to its defence against the interjection of my friend Senator Schacht from South Australia, who is a most delightful aging rocker but I think he has his broadcasting priorities entirely wrong.

Similarly, the work done by Norman Swan about the McBride investigations is an important contribution not only to scientific debate but to the standards of intellectual integrity and intellectual life of this country. Whether it be radio programs concerning war crimes allegations or television programs such as those dealing with police corruption in Queensland, the ABC can claim to have led to a situation-no commercial television station can claim this-in which it has prompted significant action by governments to respond to reports. In the few minutes available to me I would also say that the contribution of the ABC in particular to country and rural broadcasting is of enormous importance, being the primary means of communication and information distribution in the largest part of Australia. The role of Radio Australia has been alluded to by Senator Messner and I entirely endorse his remarks.

The final point I make concerns the role of the ABC in the promotion of the arts in general. The ABC's annual report indicates that the Australian content of ABC television was 52.4 per cent. While it acknowledges that its drama production in 1986-87 was only 35 hours-as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, commercial stations are required to broadcast 104 hours and the ABC has a long way to go to get up to those standards-nevertheless it is clear the contribution the ABC makes to the performing arts in Australia is of enormous importance. In its current brochure Tough Options it draws attention to the fact that the six ABC orchestras attract more than one million concert patrons a year. Frankly, without the contribution by the State orchestras maintained by the ABC there would be a great shortage of access-and that is the important thing-for ordinary Australians, no matter where they might live, to quality orchestral music. So the contribution of the ABC as a specialist broadcaster in areas such as science, investigative political journalism, rural broadcasting, the arts, the ABC orchestras, the education and children's programs and Radio Australia is entirely acknowledged. The Corporation is the major provider of arts, education and children's programming in popular broadcasting. The ABC broadcasts approximately 40 per cent of its material in those categories compared with the commercial stations' output of 17 per cent.

Time has not allowed me to go into an analysis of all the financial claims which Senator Powell made. One has to be cognisant of the remarks that Senator Schacht made about the need for financial restraint in a number of areas. Those do have to borne in mind: they are serious criticisms. Nevertheless, there is a need to preserve the national broadcaster free from Government interference and to recognise the specialist role of the ABC. I believe this will become more important as networking-indeed, networking out of Los Angeles-becomes the dominant feature of commercial broadcasting in Australia. The role of the ABC will be important not only in that specialist area but indeed in the preservation of whatever will be left of localism, local input and the reflection of Australian culture, Australian heritage and the interests of Australian citizens. To that extent, I am glad to have had the opportunity to make some remarks about the ABC and I am pleased that this matter of public importance has been brought before the Senate.

We're at the cliff's edge. I've been with the ABC 22 years, and I see this crisis as now absolutely catastrophic. People will only realise the loss when the next round of cuts occur. It may be too late then.

Political interference could not be more obvious than the well known remark of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the effect that we do not pay the ABC to run stories on Sir Peter Abeles. Senator Puplick has already referred to that. We all know of the disturbing collusion between the Prime Minister and the big boys of Australian business. How sickening it was to see-incidentally, on the ABC-the Prime Minister grovelling before Kerry Packer and Alan Bond at the glittering gathering of the 500 Club.

It makes one wonder whether the censorship applied to Pilger's television documentary The Last Dream last Sunday night was the result of political interference or whether it was motivated by self-regulation. In either case, it was a disgrace. This program was first promoted by the ABC as the conscience of the Bicentennial. There was first a disclaimer on that conscience and then a cut to the program, despite the fact that there was an indemnity against legal action, of which the ABC was well aware. It is a sign of worse things to come, I believe, if the ABC's independence is not preserved. The ABC's independence is being undermined at the moment and is in danger of being totally lost. Senator Puplick asked a very good question about Wendy Bacon's appointment. She was sacked before she started. Whose influence was that?

The ABC urgently needs help. It needs the active support of listeners and viewers to protect its existence in its present form. We cannot let 1988, our bicentennial year, also become known as the year in which the ABC went commercial. That would be a great shame indeed. Last night 3,000 people packed the Perth Concert Hall in support of the ABC. Tonight there is to be a meeting called by the Friends of the ABC in Sydney. The ABC is appealing publicly to its listeners and viewers to give it support, and that support is forthcoming. Particularly from the point of view of Western Australian listeners and viewers-we suffer from the Cinderella syndrome or the tyranny of distance in the west-the ABC is often the only way for us to get an idea of what is going on on the other side of the country. It is most important that we maintain the services of the ABC to keep us in touch with what is going on where most people seem to think the power lies in this country.

It is historically true that the ABC has offended all governments. That is absolutely appropriate. If its independence is to be maintained, it is right and fitting that it should offend government. Its job is to investigate, to question, to challenge. It should do that. It is a good thing that it should be criticised by all governments rather then being stomped on. That is occurring at the moment. The ABC is so afraid that it will not continue to get Government funding because it is being stomped on and interfered with by the politicians and the bureaucrats in Canberra that its independence is in great jeopardy. I cannot believe Senator Richardson's assurances that the Government has not threatened cuts and is not seeking outside non-government funding sources. Of course the ABC and the SBS need security. They need at least three-year budget plans so that they know exactly where they stand.

I am pleased to hear that there are no plans to merge the ABC and the SBS. They serve valuable and different sectors of the Australian community. But I am not reassured by Senator Richardson that no decisions have yet been made. Often when the Government calls for public debate, that means that the plan is to defuse public concern. That there are public meetings taking place all around the country this week is a reflection of that. The Government ought to take note of the huge public meetings that are occurring around the country this week. It ought to take note of the enormous support that the ABC has in its present form. It actually needs an increase in funding so that it can restore some of the staff levels it used to have, so that people are not worked to a frazzle trying to keep up the high standards. People are calling not only for a continuation of the ABC and SBS programs but most importantly for independent funding. Australians are very clearly saying that the ABC and the SBS should not be maintained by commercial funding. That would change the nature of the ABC and the SBS altogether. Hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians want the ABC funded by the taxpayers' dollars. We are prepared to pay for the ABC to continue its excellent service-at our expense. That is the bottom line. Most of the ABC's supporters would want an increase in funding, but neither we nor the ABC's staff are being greedy at this stage when the very existence of it as we know it is threatened.

Since June 1985 the ABC's staff has been cut by 10.2 per cent; 708 jobs have been lost. That is a huge cut already and the ABC cannot sustain more. As ABC staffer, Bob Wilcox, Perth Manager of ABC Television, said yesterday:
We (ABC staffers) feel we have nothing left to lose. We unashamedly seek public support for continued independence.
The people of Australia are responding to that call. We hope that the Government does too by at the very least maintaining the current level of government funding.

On two occasions Senator Crowley has raised with me the results of testing of the Parliament House air-conditioning system and therefore, for the information of honourable senators, I bring to the attention of the Senate the results of the most recent tests for legionella bacteria in the Parliament House air-conditioning systems.

INTERJECT.PARA: By way of background, tests for legionella bacteria have been undertaken on water cooling towers associated with the air-conditioning systems in Parliament House since 1981. Regular dumping of the water, scrubbing of the tanks and dosing with approved chemicals has been maintained.

During tests in October 1987 very low levels of legionella bacteria-10 colony forming units per millilitre-were reported in the Prime Minister's and East Block water cooling towers. I have been informed that this level was too low to pose a health hazard. That opinion was based on advice from a microbiologist and a technical information paper issued by the mechanical branch of the then Department of Housing and Construction in April 1987, entitled Measures to Control Legionnaire's Disease Hazards in Buildings, which advises that maintenance procedures are satisfactory where colony counts in the order 0 to 20 colony forming units per millilitre are found. Nevertheless, upon receipt of the test results, the contents of both water cooling towers were dumped, the tanks scrubbed and further chemical dosing was carried out.

Further testing was carried out during January this year and inquiries by the Parliament's chief engineer this morning chasing up the test results for this latest testing has brought to light evidence of legionella bozemanii, a non-pathogenic legionella bacteria. The microbiologist engaged by the testing firm, Maxwell Chemicals Pty Ltd of Sydney, stressed to the Parliament's chief engineer that legionella bozemanii is non- pathogenic and should not be confused with legionella pneumophila, which is the bacteria associated with the commonly-named legionnaire's disease.

I further inform the Senate that the latest decontamination of the Parliament's water cooling tower system was carried out on 30 January 1988. The Parliament's chief engineer has arranged for the water treatment manager of Maxwell Chemicals Pty Ltd of Sydney to meet with him on 25 February to see if any further measures or procedures can be undertaken. Arrangements are also being made for an inspection and report on appropriate preventative measures to be undertaken with regard to the new Parliament House air-conditioning system.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Provisional Taxation-Tariffs: Motor Vehicle Parts-Australian Labor Party New South Wales: Advertisements-Mr Fred Phillips: Bridging the Gap Organisation-Corryong: Victoria

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a couple of matters during the adjournment debate tonight. They are mundane matters that affect many people in this country at present. You may recall, Mr President, that on 10 December 1987, when speaking on a taxation Bill, I mentioned that the Government should look at the idea of increasing the threshold for the payment of provisional tax. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government next considers reforming the tax laws I hope it will look at the theshold for the payment of provisional tax.

The threshold at that time was $999. At that time I said that it was a disincentive to saving, and that there were young and old people alike who tended to spend that part of their savings above the level at which they would have to pay provisional tax. Last weekend I read an article in the Sydney Sunday Telegraph headed, `Labor faces a new ``Adelaide earthquake'' '. I will not dwell on the misfortunes of the Australian Labor Party in Adelaide, but I will point out a few facts contained in that article, which read:
About 350,000 pensioners face the chilling prospect of a provisional tax bill this year.
Of two million aged pensioners and veterans, about 350,000-or almost one-third more than three years ago-are estimated by the Tax Office to be liable for more tax.
Those who earn more than the $999 threshold-a rate fixed nine years ago-in income from interest, dividends, or returns from other investments, will be forced to cough up.
I don't think it was ever meant to get people on low incomes and fixed incomes, and say to them, ``This year, when you have earned that extra $1,000, you will be double taxed''.'
The point about this article that I like is that obviously the writer got some information from Treasury. I will read what the article states that the Treasury said:
According to Treasury experts, it would cost the Government only $20 million to raise the threshold from $999 to $2,000. Such a move already is widely supported in Caucus-
the Treasury did not state that the move was widely supported in Caucus; its statement ended with the reference to the figure of $2,000-
and backbenchers see it as money well spent.

But it is not a matter of spending money. If the threshold is raised from $1,000 in round figures-and I use that figure instead of saying $999 each time-to $2,000, no tax is forgone; it is merely extended into the next year. Those who pay provisional tax will find that, instead of paying it by 31 March, it will be paid in the next financial year. In other words, average wage earners will have to pay their tax bill by about September. So it is a lie for the Treasury to say that it would cost the Government $20m. I would like the Treasury, if it gives such information to newspapers, to give the whole information so that people can judge for themselves exactly what figure the Government would forgo, which is absolutely nil. As I said, it is a disincentive to saving.

The threshold, as I said, was set in 1979. What can we buy now for the same price that we would have paid in 1979? We could not buy a bus ticket or anything else. It is ridiculous even to contemplate it. In 1979, from what I can remember, the figure for average earnings was $12,000 a year. I understand that the figure is now about $24,000. So on that basis alone the threshold should be at least doubled. Having regard to the high interest rates of the last couple of years which are still fairly prevalent, a person would need only a small amount of savings, probably about $9,000, to receive unearned income of $999. As I have said before, this leads to unnecessary spending in order to avoid paying provisional tax. We are told by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that it is time to save. I agree that it is time to save. We are living in a slightly uncertain era; even the Government will admit to that. It is supposed to be a time of saving, but this is certainly not a way to save.

As the article stated, it is not only pensioners who are affected. A case was pointed out to me today of a married couple who have been saving for quite a few years for a deposit for a house. Now that their deposit has reached such a level that they may be able to start to look for a house, they have been lumbered with a provisional tax bill which means they are virtually being double taxed and they will either have to wait another year to look for a house or have their deposit drastically reduced. It is up to the Government to increase that threshold from $999 to at least $2,500 and remove these disincentives to saving. I consider that the Government should not wait until the May mini-Budget to do so; it should do so immediately.

I wish to raise another point this evening. Mr President, you may remember that in the last session of Parliament I asked various questions about the harmonising of tariffs that this Government has introduced. In particular, I refer to import duty on turbo-charger parts and diesel fuel injector parts. I received from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) various replies as to how that scheme would be put into action so that the tariff on certain parts would remain at the 2 per cent level. It should be borne in mind that these are special parts that are manufactured elsewhere, not in Australia. The tariff on turbo-charger parts is to remain at 2 per cent, but nothing has been done in regard to fuel injector parts and I understand that nothing will be done until at least April.

My fears were not ill-founded. Because there has been no dispensation to reduce the 25 per cent tariff on certain parts to 2 per cent-although in certain cases the applications were lodged last July-the importers have stopped importing these parts while they have awaited a decision. Supplies of those parts have diminished. People are importing these parts only if it is absolutely necessary. If a machine breaks down, the repair shop tells the customer, `The part has to come from overseas, there will be a 25 per cent tariff on it, compounded by sales tax. Do you want it or not?'. The customers must make up their minds. Of course, if they earn their livelihood from the machine that has broken down, they are caught by the throat and they have to say yes. It should be borne in mind that such importations of parts are a one-off exercise, so the cost of importing a particular part would rise much quicker because of freight costs and so on. An example was given to me today of a part which, under the old system, cost $500. The part must be imported from New Zealand. I do not know why New Zealand holds better stocks of these parts than Australia does. perhaps it does not have the import problems that we have. Instead of costing $500, it costs $1,000.

As I have said, these stocks are running down. I have been told by importers that we will reach a bad position by about the end of March. These diesel injection parts are used widely in the transport and earthmoving industries. Of course, Australia cannot run without its land transport, and our earthmoving industry affects road making, mining and anything one likes to mention. As I have said, the crisis will come in April. Stocks will run down. When they do, from my experience it will take a long time to get things moving. Even if the okay comes through to reduce the duty from 25 per cent back to 2 per cent, it takes a long time to get goods onto the wharf and then onto the water, or onto planes, and get them here. So the crisis will continue well into the year.

I am asking the Government to look once again at this tardy decision it has made, and to get things moving, because of the fears I have. It is no great hassle to look into this, because after all the inquiries into these parts, into whether they are made in Australia or are available here, have been done in the past. It is only because of the new harmonisation system that the Government, through its Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, has made all the industries go back to reapply. It can be easily demonstrated that these parts are not made in Australia, so it would be a simple task for the Department to give them the okay, reduce the tariff back to 2 per cent and get stocks of those parts moving into Australia because certainly we do not want half of Australia's transport system and earthmoving industry bogged down well into the new year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on a matter that concerns the New South Wales election, and also on various matters that I have dealt with in part in previous speeches in this House. In particular, I wish to extend my comments on some of those matters I have dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: On 15 February 1988 the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, Mr Peter Collins, issued a Press release saying that the continued misuse of public funds for Australian Labor Party (ALP) pre-election propaganda will be challenged in the courts. The findings are, from the advice we have had, that a plethora of case law will indeed back up such a challenge. In the 1978 case of Kanan v. Hawkins, Mr Justice Sweeney said:
If in a general election . . . a government used public moneys and public civil servants to produce propaganda . . . that action would be completely condemned.

On a previous occasion I mentioned that a whole series of advertisements had been used throughout New South Wales, estimated to have cost some $8m of taxpayers' money. That money was used on propaganda for the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party. On that occasion I cited Surfline, which had an admitted-to budget of $330,000 and a recognised known cost of $1.1m. The aim of that advertisement was to counter Opposition and environmental groups' disclosures that Sydney waterways and beaches often suffer from serious pollution, including sewage. I cited the Tangara train advertisements, estimated to have cost $1m. The aim of that advertisement was to counter Opposition attacks on the age and quality of State Rail Authority rolling stock, using the prototype of the next generation of New South Wales trains. I cited the advertisements concerning school discipline, with an estimated cost of $1m, to counter the Opposition's policies on improving school discipline and education standards.

I cited also Neighbourhood Watch advertisements aimed at countering Opposition disclosures about the breakdown of law and order and which sought to revive public commitments to Neighbourhood Watch schemes following reports of a downturn as a result of inadequate police resources to service Neighbourhood Watch commitments. The value of those commercials was in the vicinity of $1m. The final advertisement I cited was in the housing area, and it was called Homesick Blues. The aim of this advertisement was to play down the public housing crisis in New South Wales, highlighted by the New South Wales Opposition. The estimated cost of this could not be less than $1m, and it replaced the earlier advertisements, called barbecue ads, featuring none other than the Minister for Housing, Mr Frank Walker. The point has been made-it has been made strongly and it will be backed up-that this is a rorting of the system, of taxpayers' money. Something in the vicinity of $8m has been squandered in an improper manner.

I now come to a new allegation which compounds the evidence of wastage I have just given to the Senate. An allegation has been made by a group which calls itself the Eden-Monaro Survival Group. This Group makes reference to an incident which took place on 28 January, involving the use of a National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales helicopter and a fixed-wing aircraft being used at that time to fight a huge fire in the wilderness area in the south of the State and across into Victoria. The aircraft were diverted to shoot ALP advertisements for the coming election. Mr Rankin, the spokesman for the group, said that while volunteer bushfire fighters and New South Wales Forestry Commission staff were involved in fighting the blaze, the two aircraft were suddenly ordered out of the fight to participate in filming material for the ALP's State election campaign. He said:

The fire was totally out of control at the time-and the two aircraft, which were helping to fight the fire, were ordered out of the fight. It is a clear demonstration of the cynicism of the State Government and an indictment of the Minister for Planning and the Environment, Mr Carr, and the Premier, Mr Unsworth.

The aircraft were identified as bearing the markings VH-NPW-owned by the National Parks and Wildlife Service-and VH-PTH, which Mr Rankin alleges is also owned by the Service. The Government had admitted to using National Parks and Wildlife Service officers to help in its political campaign. An officer of the Service was recently involved in helping a film crew from John Singleton's advertising agency shoot a commercial to attack the forest industries on the south coast. The crew, apparently using public funds, chartered a helicopter, and an officer of the Service was involved in supervising the flight to spy on the logging areas. It is obvious that Mr Carr and Mr Unsworth will stop at nothing to denigrate workers in the forest industries. They have turned their backs on traditional Labor voters. The Government will now have to face the consequences.

They are the allegations set out in the Press release issued by the Eden-Monaro Survival Group on 24 February. I can add, in terms of information received, that the aircraft with the serial number VH-NPW is a fixed-wing aircraft owned by the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales and that the aircraft VH-PTH is a Squirrel helicopter, painted blue and white, also owned by the National Parks and Wildlife Service. I can further inform the Senate that the name of the pilot of that aircraft was either George or Steve, who usually fly that particular aircraft. It is interesting that the normal method of operation of those aircraft is this: When they go such an operation-that is fighting bushfires-they have a standard, broad flight plan which is approved. Should they deviate from that flight plan they radio a schedule change which may or may not be logged. It may be logged by the pilot; it may also be logged by the Department. However, records of those changes are kept for three weeks only. That incident occurred on 28 January. Another record is kept of these flights. It is known, with regard to the Squirrel helicopter, as the helicopter trips records of the day. Those records are filed with and kept by the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales.

The purpose of my raising this matter in this place is quite simple: I call upon the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in the Federal Government to take note of the serious allegations made by the Eden-Monaro survival group. He should see whether or not the logs of the flight patterns of those two aircraft are still in existence. Should that not be the case he should call upon his New South Wales colleagues-indeed, I think it is not too fine a point to say `friends and colleagues'-for the helicopter trip records of the day to be released by the Unsworth Government so that he may determine whether not only New South Wales but also Victoria were left at risk to the serious bushfires that traverse those States while those aircraft were used for political purposes.

Going back to the legal cases that are cited, quite properly the advertisements which I have mentioned earlier ought to have been paid for by the ALP. They ought to have been authorised by Stephen Loosley. There is ample case law on the point. It is yet another example of the hypocrisy and the subterfuge that the Labor Government, the Unsworth Government in New South Wales, will stoop to to try to hold office at all costs. We have seen yet again a revival of an advertising technique used by Mr Singleton in a previous election. This time he seems to have used an up-market version of whingeing Wendy. Perhaps the rhetoric that she uses could best be applied to self; that is, the Unsworth Government. When she says, `I don't mean to be rude', she should direct that to Mr Unsworth. The question she should ask is, `But how much more of taxpayers' money will you be wasting on your advertisements which ought properly to be paid for by the Australian Labor Party and authorised by Mr Stephen Loosley?'.

The allegations are serious ones. In calling on the Federal Minister to investigate them, I do so because he has a responsibility in the area. I do so knowing the ethos of the mateship of the right wing Labor machine in New South Wales. It will be a test indeed for the Minister to have the courage to find if the records are available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the Senate's attention with regret the recent death of Mr Fred Phillips who was the founder and National Director of an organisation called Bridging the Gap. Bridging the Gap is a non-profit organisation that was set up about seven years ago by Fred Phillips. In the seven years since its inception it has placed 12,000 young people in work throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Phillips was a remarkable man. He established this organisation seven years ago almost by chance. He was forced to retire from the business world after a heart attack and as part of the recuperation from that heart attack he was engaged in lengthy walking each day. In the course of these walks he came across the same group of young, lethargic youths out of work outside the local pinball shop. He would ask them what they were doing there. They said that there was no work and that they had given up looking for it. So he said to them, `If I find you work, would you be willing to take it?'. They said that they would. So Fred Phillips then canvassed the local businesses in his area, which was the Noble Park area of Melbourne. He approached 52 companies and asked an executive from each company to become a coach to help a young person get a job. He also nominated local teachers and asked them to nominate the slow learners and the low achievers in their senior classes. These young people were sent to the coaches who gave them direction and encouragement and either found them a job with their own company or found them a job amongst friends and associates. In the first three months of this activity he had filled 58 jobs and since then, as I have said, the organisation has not looked back and has now placed 12,000 young people in work.

Bridging the Gap goes far beyond any service provided by other employment agencies and, in particular, far beyond that provided by the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). The program pursues a course of education, helping youth to find employment. As I said, it asks companies to act as volunteers in coaching, providing unemployed youth with advice, encouragement and direction. The program looks at young people to see whether they are equipped with the training, experience or the appearance and whether they are likely to be seen to be acceptable in employment. If a judgment was made that they were not, they would undertake a course with the Bridging the Gap organisation of two and a half hours or so during which time they would be taught such basic things as dressing properly, how to handle themselves in a work environment, punctuality and so on. Indeed, Fred Phillips found to his amazement on one occasion a large group of 18-year-olds who had never had a conversation with an adult. They had never shaken hands with an adult. So he taught them the basics of shaking hands and of being able to converse with adults without which employment prospects for those young people would be virtually nil.

The Bridging the Gap organisation has, to my knowledge, received no government funding at all, certainly not from the Commonwealth Government. Fred Phillips believed that accepting money from government would even be counter-productive because the businessmen with whom he worked so closely in finding jobs would see government programs as being programs that they did not trust.

It is very interesting to compare the cost of the Fred Phillips placement program with that of the Commonwealth Employment Service. The cost of placing people in jobs under the Bridging the Gap organisation has been approximately $50 a placement. The average cost under the Commonwealth Employment Service placement program is, I understand, of the order of $900 to $1,000. Indeed, when we look at some of the government programs for employment-for example, the now abandoned community employment program-the average cost of placing all unemployed young people in jobs under that program was calculated a couple of years ago at a staggering $23,000 a placement.

So, without having received government assistance, the Bridging the Gap organisation has placed 12,000 people in jobs. Indeed, it has 11 or a dozen officers around Australia running its program on a shoestring. It has been successful because it concentrates on the importance of fostering enthusiasm and self-confidence in unemployed young people. It ensures that they are well presented and equipped with the right information and realistic expectations about what they can do and aim for. Fred Phillips should be honoured for his great achievements in the work that he has done under that program over the last seven years of his life before his untimely death.

All of us could learn from the attitude that he adopted in dealing with and working with young people who were trying to find their place in society, and particularly their place in employment. He worked on the premise that the best form of welfare and the best morale booster for any young person is work, and that virtually any job, even if initially it was of low status and low pay, was better than no job. He was a great advocate of teaching that ethic in school. He found, as I think many of us have discovered, that that is an ethic that is not properly and adequately taught in schools today. A memorial to Fred Phillips could perhaps be a program to encourage the teaching of those values in our schools.

Fred Phillips had some other ideas to which I believe we should give some thought. For example, he was a strong advocate of the concept of putting a limit on the period that any person can receive the unemployment benefit. That is the situation in many overseas countries. In this country the period is unlimited. I agree with Fred Phillips that continued payment of the dole or the unemployment benefit should be conditional upon the recipient's willingness to undergo training and to have his situation reviewed after a certain period. Those matters have been examined in the past, and I believe they should be examined again in the future.

Fred Phillips was not as well known in the community as I believe he and his program deserved. Whilst expressing sadness at his passing, I welcome the opportunity to applaud the work that he did in order to bring it to the attention of the community. We must not allow that man's death to mean the end of the tremendous work that he has achieved in the Bridging the Gap organisation. The task of following him has been filled by Mr McNeill in South Australia. He has become the new national co-ordinator of the Bridging the Gap organisation. I hope that the community and government will follow the work of the Bridging the Gap organisation, not necessarily by providing financial assistance but at least by providing moral support. We should do what we can to assist the organisation's program, as it has proved itself to be of great value to many thousands of disadvantaged young people. That could be no greater memorial to any person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate the small and uniquely picturesque alpine township of Corryong in Victoria. The history of Corryong dates back to 1875 but the heritage of Corryong is the heritage of Australia, for Corryong well represents all that first attracted the early settlers to this land and motivated the pioneering spirit in Australia. Nestled in the foothills of the Snowy Mountains, it is indeed the gateway to the majestic mountains that are one of the grandest gifts that nature has given us. From those mountains have come Australia's greatest legends-legends of the men and women of the High Country; legends that depict the spirit of the nation and are well recorded in Australian art and literature. The legend of The Man from Snowy River, set to poetry by Banjo Paterson, combines all the qualities of the early, and indeed, the present, bush and mountain men. I believe that it is one of Australia's greatest stories. It is a Victorian story which proudly is still told today.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true of late that there has been some serious debate concerning who was the Man from Snowy River, as depicted by Banjo Paterson. This debate has gained wide coverage, particularly in the Melbourne Sun. I wish to lend my support to the long held belief that Jack Riley was the mountain man who hailed from Snowy River on the Kosciusko side, the man that only Clancy stood his friend. The story of Jack Riley being the Man from Snowy River is a very reliable one. It is reliable because it has been passed down from father to son, neighbour to neighbour and told many times around the camp fire. I accept that while legends and stories may grow bigger as time rolls on, the core of truth of any great story such as this does not change. I would like to refer to an article in the Corryong Courier of 23 July 1914 which pays tribute to Jack Riley on the occasion of his death. It said:

A fearless and dashing horseman in his young days, a first class hand among stock, and with all an Irishman's open handed generosity he was liked and respected by all who knew him. In bushcraft, even among the experts of the Murray, Gippsland and the Monaro, he stood alone, and it is said that some of his exploits form the basis of Paterson's well known verses on `The Man from Snowy River'.
I would like to read to the Senate an article which contains the story that was told to Thomas Mitchell as a child by his father. The article states:

My father (the late Walter Edward Mitchell) took Paterson on his first trip up Kosciusko. They spent the night with Jack Riley and Paterson (affectionately known as `Banjo') told me later that he was listening to Jack Riley's yarns that gave him the idea of the Man from Snowy River.

That is good enough for me as evidence that Jack Riley was the Man from Snowy River. Today as we celebrate our bicentennial year, it is a time to reflect on our traditional beliefs and on the past Australians who shaped this nation. Banjo Paterson wrote of the Man from Snowy River, Henry Lawson wrote of the Drover's Wife and Francis Adams wrote of the Bushman. Today, whether we live in city or country, we can all personally relate to those hardships of our pioneering ancestors up to 200 years ago. We do not have to look too far back in time to know the effects of our natural environment on the Australian character. I remind my fellow senators of the impact of the Ash Wednesday bushfires of 1983 upon the people of Victoria. It is those same harsh realities faced by past and present Australians that have inspired the great qualities of a people strong in will, with a very fine spirit and a sense of mateship to be passed on through the generations to this very moment in time. I believe that this should be the pride of our bicentennial year and the foundation for our next 200 years. In conclusion, Ian Mudie gives us a picture of Australia as it is now and as it was 200 years ago. He said:
Give my words sun and rain,
desert and heat and mist,
spring flowers, and dead grass,
blue sea and dusty sky,
song-birds and harsh cries,
strength and austerity
that this land has.
